   133.01 APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES OF VILLAGE FISCAL OFFICER.
   (a)   There is hereby created the full-time position of Village Fiscal
Officer. The Village Fiscal Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
the confirmation by Council. The Village Fiscal Officer shall be responsible
for the collection, disbursement and custody of all funds of the Village and
shall establish and maintain those records and procedures necessary to perform
the duties of the office. For any disbursement made by the Village Fiscal
Officer greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the Mayor shall also
approve and sign such instrument. The Village Fiscal Officer shall act as
liaison between the Finance Committee, Mayor, and Council, and shall perform
such other functions as may be assigned by the Mayor or by ordinance or
resolution of Council. (Ord. 4071. Passed 6-17-20.)
   (b)   The Village Fiscal Officer shall have those powers, duties and
functions as provided by the general laws of the State of Ohio. All such
general laws pertaining to a Village Clerk and a Village Treasurer shall apply
to the Village Fiscal Officer. In addition, such Village Fiscal Officer shall
be responsible for all the duties and procedures set forth in subsection (a)
above and shall maintain the Drug Offenses Trust Fund as established by
Bratenahl Codified Ordinance
 135.03.
   (c)   The Village Fiscal Officer shall also serve as Clerk of Council and,
as such, shall keep the journal of Council, an accurate and complete record of
all proceedings of Council authenticated by his or her signature and have
custody of all laws, ordinances and resolutions of Council; have custody of all
official documents, reports, papers and files of Council, and shall perform
other such duties as Council shall require.
(Ord. 3905. Passed 1-18-17.)
   (d)   The Village Fiscal Officer shall also serve as the Village Tax
Administrator who shall be responsible for the collection and deposit to the
municipal treasury of municipal income taxes and the enforcement and
administration of the municipal corporation’s income tax ordinances,
resolutions, and rules including the powers, duties, and authority as set forth
in Codified Ordinance Chapter
171 and
173.
   (e)   The Village Fiscal Officer shall have such assistance as provided by
Ordinance of Council.
   (f)   The Village Fiscal Officer may be removed with or without cause by the
Mayor with the consent of a majority of the Village Council. Should the Village
Fiscal Officer voluntarily leave, he/she shall give the Village at least thirty
(30) days notice.
(Ord. 4097. Passed 2-17-21.)
   133.02 COMPENSATION OF VILLAGE FISCAL OFFICER.
   The salary of the Village Fiscal Officer shall be as provided by Council
from time to time. The Village Fiscal Officer shall be entitled to participate
in the OPERS pension benefit. (Ord. 3911. Passed 2-15-17.)
   133.03 BOND.
   The Village Fiscal Officer shall be bonded in the sum of fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000), the premium of which shall be paid by the Village.
(Ord. 3905. Passed 1-18-17.)
   133.04 NO RESIDENCY REQUIRED.
   The Village Fiscal Officer does not have to be a resident of the Village at
the time of appointment or at any time thereafter.
(Ord. 3905. Passed 1-18-17.)
   133.05 DEPUTY FISCAL OFFICER.
   (a)   The full-time position of Deputy Fiscal Officer is hereby created.
   (b)   The Deputy Fiscal Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall
act under the direction of the Mayor and the Village Fiscal Officer, subject to
confirmation by the Council.
   (c)   The Deputy Fiscal Officer shall render all such assistance to the
Village Fiscal Officer as the Village Fiscal Officer may require and, during
any period when the Village Fiscal Officer is absent or unavailable or unable
for any cause to perform his/her duties, shall be the Acting Village Fiscal
Officer and shall have full power and authority to perform all things which the
Village Fiscal Officer is authorized or required to perform.
   (d)   The Deputy Fiscal Officer shall be compensated at a rate fixed from
time to time by the Council and authorized by ordinance.
   (e)   The Deputy Fiscal Officer shall furnish bond to the Village, at its
cost, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000). (Ord. 3913. Passed 2-15-17.)
   133.06 PART-TIME ASSISTANT DEPUTY FISCAL OFFICER.
   (a)   The part-time position of Assistant Deputy Fiscal Officer is hereby
created.
   (b)   The Part-Time Assistant Deputy Fiscal Officer shall be appointed by
the Mayor and shall act under the direction of the Mayor and the Village Fiscal
Officer, subject to confirmation by the Council.
   (c)   The Part-Time Assistant Deputy Fiscal Officer shall render all such
assistance to the Mayor or the Village Fiscal Officer as the Mayor or the
Village Fiscal Officer may require.
   (d)   The Part-Time Assistant Deputy Fiscal Officer shall be compensated as
may be provided by Village Council and shall be entitled to participate in the
OPERS pension benefit.
   (e)   The Part-Time Assistant Deputy Fiscal Officer shall furnish bond to
the Village, at its costs, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000).
(Ord. 4098. Passed 2-17-21.)
   133.07  CREDIT CARD POLICY.
   Council hereby adopts the Credit Card Policy attached to Ordinance 4009 as
Exhibit “A” for the use of the Village of Bratenahl’s credit card accounts.
(Ord. 4009. Passed 1-16-19.)
CHAPTER 139
Police Department
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Ordinance 593, passed November 17, 1950, created a municipal
Police Relief and Pension Fund. House Bill 642, enacted by the 1965 session of
the 106th Ohio General Assembly, established Ohio R.C. Chapter 742 and created
a Statewide disability and pension fund for policemen and firemen and abolishes
all municipal police relief and pension funds as of January 1, 1967.

   139.01 PERSONNEL.
   The Police Department shall consist of a Marshal, designated Chief of
Police, and Deputy Marshals, herein designated as Lieutenant, Sergeant, and
police officers. The Department shall consist of a Chief of Police, and may
include Lieutenants, Sergeants, Police Officers, Dispatch Supervisors,
Dispatchers, and such other part-time auxiliary officers and Dispatchers as are
approved by Council. (Ord. 3660. Passed 6-18-14.)
   139.02 APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS.
   The regular members of the Police Department shall be appointed by the
Mayor, subject to confirmation by Council. The Mayor may promote a member to
fill a vacancy.
(Ord. 2809. Passed 9-20-95.)
   139.03 COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Appointments and promotions in positions in the Police Department, and
the employment of members thereof, shall be made only within the appropriation
of Council for such purpose. The various officers of the Department shall
receive such compensation as fixed and authorized by ordinance.
(Ord. 3924. Passed 6-21-17.)
   (b)   The Mayor shall, when making new appointments in the Police
Department, provide a tenure credit not to exceed seventy-five percent (75%)
for previous service in other police departments upon proof such service. For
any appointment from July 16, 2014 to the effective date of the 2018 amendment
to Section
149.10 of the Codified Ordinances, such tenure credit above shall also apply
for military service credit. For any other full time members with previous
military service, Section
149.10(c) shall apply.
(Ord. 4032. Passed 6-19-19; Ord. 4035. Passed 7-17-19.)
   (c)   Effective July 19, 2023, all full-time and part-time members of the
Police Department who have successfully completed their probationary period,
are eligible for a marksmanship incentive in the amount of two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) annually for full-time members and seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) annually for part-time members to be paid in the first pay period of
December of each year. To qualify for such an incentive, the member must
achieve at least a passing score of ninety-five percent (95%) or greater on
such member’s annual firearms requalification. (Ord. 4187. Passed 7-22-23.)
   139.04 POWERS AND DUTIES OF POLICE CHIEF.
   The Chief of Police, as Marshal, shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to
confirmation by Council. The appointee need not be a resident of the Village at
the time of his appointment, but shall become a resident thereof within six
months after his appointment by the Mayor and confirmation by Council, unless
such residence requirement is waived by ordinance. He shall be the head, under
the Mayor, of the Police Department. He shall station all other officers in the
Department under the general rules and regulations as the Mayor may prescribe.
In case of any infraction, insubordination, malfeasance, misfeasance,
nonfeasance, or in case of any other cause for suspension or discipline, under
the laws of the State, of any member, the Chief shall forthwith file a full
report in writing with the Mayor.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.05 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   All regular appointments to the Police Department shall be for a
probationary period of twelve (12) months’ continuous service, and no
appointment shall be finally made until the appointee has satisfactorily served
his probationary period. At the end of the probationary period, the Mayor shall
transmit to Council a record of such member’s service with his recommendations
thereon, and the Mayor may, with the concurrence of Council, remove or finally
appoint the member to the rank or position to be filled. (Ord. 3662. Passed 6-
18-14.)
   139.06 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Chief of Police, as Marshal, and all other members of the Police
Department, as Deputy Marshals, shall have and possess all powers as are
conferred by the general laws of Ohio, or by ordinance of Council, and shall
exercise all authority pertaining thereto.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.07 SUSPENSION OR REMOVAL.
   All officers of the Police Department shall be subject to suspension or
removal as provided by the general laws of Ohio.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.08 SUPERVISION; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor shall have all powers and duties connected with and incident to
the governing of the Police Department, except the stationing of officers,
which shall be under the control of the Chief of Police, but under such general
rules and regulations as the Mayor may prescribe. The Mayor may further
prescribe rules and regulations for the management, regulation and government
of the Department and of its members.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.09 ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   In the case of an original appointment, except as to the Chief of Police, no
person shall be eligible for appointment, or be appointed, as a member of the
Police Department whose age is less than twenty-one years.
(Ord. 3188. Passed 5-21-03.)
   139.10 RETIREMENT.
   No member of the Police Department shall be eligible to continue service in
the Department after December 31 of any year next following his sixty-fifth
birthday anniversary.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.11 CONTINUITY OF SERVICE.
   The acting Chief of Police, as Marshal, and all other officers of the
Department, as Deputy Marshals, shall continue in office in their same rank
from and after the effective date of this section (Ordinance 1672, passed
October 21, 1964). All such officers shall be credited with their tenure in the
present Police Department and shall retain the same rank.
(Ord. 1672. Passed 10-21-64.)
   139.12 WORK WEEK; OVERTIME.
   (a)   The work period for all members of the Police Department, shall be
fourteen consecutive days (the “Work Period”).
   (b)   Hours worked by members of the Police Department, excepting the Chief
of Police, in excess of 80 hours during the Work Period shall be considered
overtime. Hours worked include vacation leave, holiday leave and bereavement
leave but do not include sick leave and compensatory time.
   (c)   In addition to the above overtime provision, hours worked by members
of the Police Department, excepting the Chief of Police, on a day on which a
member was not scheduled for active duty, shall be considered overtime,
regardless of whether the hours worked exceed 80 in the Work Period.
   (d)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, time spent, outside normal working
hours, by a member of the Police Department attending training required by the
Police Department on a day on which they were not scheduled for active duty
shall be compensated at the normal rate of pay unless the member’s total hours
worked exceed 80 in the Work Period. Time spent, outside normal working hours,
by a member of the Police Department attending training required to maintain
their law-enforcement certification does not constitute compensable hours of
work.
   (e)   Each member shall be compensated for all overtime hours worked at the
rate of one and one-half times the member's normal rate of compensation.
   (f)   Members may elect to receive, in lieu of the above cash payment for
overtime hours worked, compensatory time for such overtime hours at the rate of
one and one-half hours of compensatory time for each hour of overtime worked.
   (g)   In no event shall a member be able to earn more than eight hours of
compensatory time in a single Work Period.
   (h)   Members may accumulate a maximum of 200 hours of compensatory time.
Accumulated compensatory time may be carried over from year to year. However,
for any member who has accumulated from 200 hours up to a maximum of 480 hours
at the time of the implementation of said maximum of 200 hours, such member
shall be paid their regular rate of pay for all such hours in excess of said
200 hours.
(Ord. 3936. Passed 9-20-17.)
   139.13 VACATIONS.
   Members shall be entitled to vacations as provided by ordinance and at such
periods as shall be provided by the Chief. Entitlement to vacation time may not
be carried over beyond the end of a calendar year.
(Ord. 1711. Passed 1-19-66.)
   139.14 PART-TIME AND AUXILIARY OFFICERS.
   In addition to the regular members of the Department, there may be part-time
and auxiliary police officers as follows:
(a)   Part-time Police Officer. Part-time Police Officers shall be appointed by
the Mayor, upon the recommendation of the Chief of Police. Prior to
appointment, Part-time Police Officers shall have completed all schooling
required by the State of Ohio Peace Officers Training Council and be state
certified.
(b)   Auxiliary Police Officers. An Auxiliary Police Officer shall work as a
volunteer, without compensation. An Auxiliary Police Officer shall be appointed
by the Mayor upon the recommendation of the Chief of Police and shall provide
his/her own equipment, except weapon and required uniform, as determined by the
Chief and Mayor. Auxiliary Police Officers shall be subject to such rules as
prescribed by the Mayor and the Chief of Police and shall assist regular full-
time and part-time Police Officers in their normal duties. Auxiliary Police
Officers shall be appointed for a period of not more than one year.
(Ord. 2809. Passed 9-20-95.)
   139.15 UNIFORM AND MAINTENANCE ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   All full time and part time members of the Police Department shall be
entitled to the following amounts as an annual uniform allowance for each year,
which is defined as January 1st to December 31st:
 
(1)    Full time members Chief of Police,Lieutenants, Sergeants, and $1,000
       Police Officers:
(2)(a) Part time Police Officers who work at least 200 hours in the  $ 500   
       prior year:
(2)(b) Part time Police Officers who work less than 200 hours in the $ 250
       prior year:
(3)    Emergency allowance for Chief of Police, Lieutenants,         $ 200
       Sergeants, and Police Officers:   
 
   (b)   This uniform allowance will be paid directly to venders or as
reimbursement to eligible employees upon presentation of receipts for the
purchase of approved uniform items.
   (c)   Such allowance shall be for the purchase of uniform items from a list
of authorized items prepared by the Police Chief and approved by the Mayor.
   (d)   In the event a part time Police Officer is elevated to full time
status throughout the year, he or she shall be entitled to the prorated
difference between the allowances in a total annual amount not to exceed $1,000
for the year.
   (e) In addition to the above, a uniform maintenance allowance of $300 per
year shall be paid semi-annually to each full time officer of the Police
Department who has worked a full time schedule for the prior six months on or
about June 15th and on or about December 15th of each year.
(Ord. 3958. Passed 2-21-18.)
   139.16 EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT UPON TERMINATION.
   (a)    All municipal employees, in consideration of their full or part time
employment with the Police Department, shall, upon acceptance of such
employment, enter into a Reimbursement Agreement providing for reimbursement to
the Village upon voluntary or involuntary termination for various expenses
incurred by the Village as follows:
      (1)   For costs of all testing, equipment, and training on the employee's
behalf, such reimbursements shall be in accordance with the following schedule:
         A.   If employee separates within one (1) year of the date of hire,
the employee shall reimburse the Village seventy-five percent (75%) of the cost
of all testing, equipment, and training.
         B.   If employee separates later than one (1) year but within two (2)
years of the date of hire, the employee shall reimburse the Village fifty
percent (50%) of the cost of all testing, equipment, and training.
      (2)   In addition, if any full or part time employee of the Police
Department leaves Village employment within the first two (2) years of his or
her employment, said employee shall reimburse the Village of Bratenahl fifty
percent (50%) for all monies expended for his or her uniform allowance and
maintenance allowance.
         (Ord. 3642. Passed 2-19-14.)
   139.17 COMPENSATORY TIME FOR WORK ON SPECIFIC HOLIDAYS.
   All full time members of the Police Department (Chief of Police,
Lieutenants, Sergeants, Police Officers, Dispatch Supervisor(s), and
Dispatchers) who work on January 1, Thanksgiving Day, and/or Christmas Day
shall be compensated with four (4) hours of compensatory time in addition to
their regular rate of pay. (Ord. 3663. Passed 6-18-14.)
   139.18 COMPENSATORY TIME FOR SENIOR OFFICER DESIGNATION.
   The Police Officer designated by the Chief of Police as Senior Officer shall
receive one (1) hour of compensatory time for each eight (8)-hour shift as
Senior Officer.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 6-18-14.)

   143.01 STREET COMMISSIONER; DUTIES.
   Council hereby establishes the office of Street Commissioner of the Village.
The Street Commissioner shall be in charge of the Service Department under the
supervision of the Mayor, and shall be responsible for collection and disposal
of garbage, rubbish or other refuse; care, repair and maintenance of streets,
sewers, water mains, sidewalks, parks, municipal buildings, property and other
equipment. In addition thereto, he shall perform such other duties as the Mayor
and Council may from time to time direct.
(Ord. 1477. Passed 11-19-58.)
   143.02 WORK WEEK AND COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The work week for all members of the Service Department, except Street
Commissioner, shall be forty (40) hours. When authorized by the Mayor or Street
Commissioner, work in excess of eight (8) hours per day and any work on
Saturdays or Sundays shall be compensated at one and one-half (1 ½) times the
employee’s hourly rate. Hours worked include vacation leave, holiday leave and
bereavement leave but do not include sick leave.
   (b)   No workday shall exceed sixteen (16) hours.
   (c)   When authorized by the Mayor or the Street Commissioner, any work on
scheduled holidays, as provided in Section
149.01, shall be compensated at two (2) times the employee’s hourly rate. (Ord.
4095. Passed 2-17-21.)
   (d)   Whenever a member of the Service Department (excluding the Director)
is called into service outside of the normal work hours (7:00 am - 3:00 pm),
that member shall have the option of receiving three (3) hours of overtime or
the equivalent amount of compensatory time. (Ord. 4178. Passed 2-15-23.)
   (e)   Whenever a member of the Service Department (excluding the Director)
has worked a regular work shift during a work week and has worked between the
hours of midnight and 7:00 am that same day, that member shall have the ability
to immediately use banked compensatory time.
(Ord. 4095. Passed 2-17-21.)
   143.03 EMPLOYMENT OF ADDITIONAL LABOR.
   The head of the Service Department and the Mayor are hereby authorized and
directed to obtain, from time to time, the services of such workmen as may be
necessary to do the work of such Department and to contract to pay fair and
proper wages for such services.
(Ord. 1188. Passed 4-19-50.)
   143.04 CARE OF VILLAGE HALL.
   (a)    The cleaning, care and maintenance of the Village Hall shall be
provided by employees in the Service Department under the supervision of the
Street Commissioner.
   (b)    Employees of the Service Department shall receive no additional
compensation for such services over their regular and established compensation.
(Ord. 1482. Passed 12-17-58.)
   143.05 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   Full time members of the Service Department shall be entitled to an
amount up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) as an annual uniform allowance for
each year, which is defined as January 1st to December 31st.
   (b)   This uniform allowance will be paid directly to vendors or as
reimbursement to eligible employees upon presentation of receipts of the
purchase of approved uniform items.
   (c)   Such allowance shall be for the purchase of uniform items from a list
of authorized items prepared by the Street Commissioner and approved by the
Mayor.
   (d)   If any full-time employee of the Service Department leaves Village
employment within the first two (2) years of his or her employment, said
employee shall reimburse the Village fifty percent (50%) for all monies
expended for his or her uniform allowance and maintenance allowance.
(Ord. 4231. Passed 12-18-24.)

   145.01 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established the position of Commissioner of Buildings of the
Village, who shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of
Council.
(Ord. 1674. Passed 10-21-64.)
   145.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commissioner of Buildings shall perform his duties under the direction
and supervision of the Mayor. He shall issue all permits required by ordinance
in the construction, demolition, alteration, repair and maintenance of
buildings and their appurtenances. It shall be his duty and responsibility to
inspect all construction work within the Village. He shall make the
intermediate and final inspections, shall have authority to adopt and
promulgate detailed guidelines for the design and installation of small cell
facilities and wireless support structures and shall have authority over the
location of buildings and structures in accordance with the provisions of the
ordinances of the Village, including the survey of any site.
   He shall be charged with enforcement of the provisions of the Building Code
and other ordinances relating to the construction, demolition, alteration,
repair, maintenance and safety of buildings and structures. He shall possess
such powers as may be vested by ordinance. He shall perform such further duties
as the Mayor or Council may require.
(Ord. 3976. Passed 5-16-18.)
 
   145.03 ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
   The Commissioner of Buildings shall administer and enforce the provisions of
the Land Planning and Zoning Code of the Village. When appointed by the
Planning Commission, he may act as its secretary and, when authorized by it,
perform such duties in connection with the business of the Commission as it may
require. He shall also perform, when requested, such duties as the Board of
Zoning Appeals may require. He shall attend all meetings of the Planning
Commission and the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Ord. 1674. Passed 10-21-64.)
   145.04 DEPUTY COMMISSIONER.
   In the event of the disability or absence for cause of the Commissioner of
Buildings, the Mayor is authorized to designate a deputy who shall exercise the
powers and perform the duties of the Commissioner during the period of such
absence or disability.
(Ord. 1674. Passed 10-21-64.)
   145.05 OCCUPANCY PERMITS.
   The Commissioner of Buildings is authorized to issue occupancy permits as
provided in the Land Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 1674. Passed 10-21-64.)
   145.06 INSPECTIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
145.06 was repealed by Ordinance 3997.
   145.07 BUILDING DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATOR.
   (a)   The position of Building Department Administrator is hereby created.
   (b)   The Building Department Administrator shall be appointed by the Mayor
and shall act under the direction of the Commissioner of Buildings.
   (c)   The Building Department Administrator shall render all such assistance
to the Commissioner of Buildings as may be required.
   (d)   The Building Department Administrator shall be compensated at a rate
fixed from time to time by the Council and authorized by ordinance.
(Ord. 3770. Passed 7-16-14.)
   145.08 BUILDING DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   The formal Bratenahl Building Department consisting of the positions
set forth in this chapter is hereby established.
   (b)   Said department shall have full authority to enforce all laws, statues
and regulations as provided and authorized in the Ohio Revised Code and the
Ohio Administrative Code pursuant to the Certification approved by an
Certification rule adopted by the Ohio Board of Building Standards, as well as
local ordinances.
(Ord. 3341. Passed 8-21-06.)
CHAPTER 147

CROSS REFERENCES

   147.01 RECREATION DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created a Department of Recreation. The Recreation
Department shall have the duty and obligation of operating the recreational
activities, functions and programs which are now or may hereafter be performed
or carried on by the Village. Council may, from time to time, designate
additional activities, functions or programs for operation by the Department,
but the Department shall immediately take charge of operating and carrying on
all recreational activities, functions or programs which are scheduled within
the parks or recreation areas owned or controlled by the Village.
(Ord. 4207. Passed 2-21-24.)
   147.02 RECREATION PROGRAM DIRECTOR.
   The Recreation Program Director shall be appointed by and serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor with the concurrence of a majority of Council. The
Director shall have supervision of the Recreation Department and all of its
employees.
   (a)   Duties of Recreation Program Director.
      (1)   Plans and manages activities, events, classes, and programs at the
Bratenahl Community Center, Village Park, including on-going and special
events, e.g., Bratenahl Home Days (annual Fireworks) and the Memorial Day
Parade. (e.g., advertises events; maintains calendar of events; coordinates
with Fire, Police and other departments on safety and security issues; orders
supplies; oversees set up for events; supervises ceremonies; monitors
facilities performance during events and troubleshoots issues related to
events,etc.); ensures individual events remain within budget; pays invoices;
collects, counts, and deposits ticket monies.
      (2)   Coordinates the rental of the Community Center and Village Park for
community events, private events, recreation leagues, community meetings and
coordinates the use of the Tennis Courts, Playground, Community Dog Park,
Community Garden and other Village amenities.
      (3)   Supervises Community Center staff and volunteers to ensure that the
Community Centeris open during regular operating hours and that basic
maintenance and cleaning operations are implemented.
      (4)   Prepares annual budget requests for Community Center and community
events for approval by the Mayor and Village Council; Monitors budget; Prepares
expense reports (e.g., collects monies; fills out report by purchase order or
credit card; makes copies; submits to Village Fiscal department; etc.);
Prepares deposits as needed (e.g. organizes monies by subject or payee; fills
out deposits slips; fills out deposit log; submits to Village Fiscal
department; etc.).
      (5)   Works with relevant commissions or committees, along with community
volunteers to solicit community input and ensure community voice in the
creation of events and programs. Attends Village Council and relevant committee
or commission meetings.
      (6)   Creatively solves problems and establishes and maintains a positive
customer service attitude.
      (7)   Prepares monthly and annual reports detailing event activity,
attendance, and revenue for review by the Mayor and Village Council.
      (8)   Prepares and distributes marketing and communication materials via
print, social media, mail, and email to promote upcoming events.
      (9)   Meets all job safety requirements and all applicable OSHA safety
standards that pertain to essential functions.
      (10)   Demonstrates regular and predictable attendance.
   (b)   Other Duties and Responsibilities. Performs other duties as required.
   (c)   Assistants to Recreation Director. The Assistants to the Recreation
Director shall be appointed by the Mayor and be under the supervision of the
Recreation Program Director to assist in the supervision of the Recreation
Department.
      (Ord. 4207. Passed 2-21-24.)
   147.03 RECREATION ADVISORY COMMISSION RE-FORMED AND RE-ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   A commission is hereby re-formed and re-established and shall be known
as the Recreation Advisory Commission, which shall consist of five or more
members who shall be residents of the Village and shall serve without pay. All
five or more members shall be appointed by the Mayor with the concurrence of
Council. All members shall be voting members.
   (b)   The Commission’s members shall be appointed for terms of one, two, and
three years respectively, commencing March 2024, and with one member’s term
expiring on December 31, 2024, two members’ terms expiring on December 31,
2025, and the remaining members’ terms expiring on December 31, 2026, and whose
successors shall be appointed for terms of three years thereafter. Prior to
expiration of a member’s term or upon a vacancy, the Recreation Program
Director shall notify the Mayor of such expiration or vacancy, and the Mayor
shall take appropriate action, with the approval of Council, to replace such
member. Any member of the Commission may be removed at the discretion of the
Mayor subject to the concurrence of a majority of the members of Council. All
vacancies on the Commission shall be filled for the balance of the unexpired
term in the same manner as the original appointment.
   (c)    The Recreation Advisory Commission shall be solely an advisory body
to the Mayor and/or Council. The Mayor and/or Council may request advice from
the Recreation Advisory Commission from time to time as deemed necessary in
their sole discretion.
   (d)    Officers: The officers shall be a Chairman and a Secretary. These
officers shall be elected by a roll call vote at the Commission’s first meeting
in January of each year. The majority vote of those appointed shall elect such
officers. Officers shall serve until their successors have been elected.
      (1)    The Chairman shall be responsible for the calling of a meeting at
the direction of the Mayor and/or Council, for the conduct of the meetings of
the Commission, and for such other duties as may be specifically designated by
the Mayor and/or Council.
      (2)    The Secretary shall be responsible for the taking and preparation
of meeting minutes.
      (3)    In the event a vacancy is determined to exist in any Commission
office for any reason whatsoever, the vacancy shall be filled in the same
manner as provided for the original appointment.
      (4)    Each officer shall be elected for a term of one year or until
their successors have been elected.
   (e)    The Commission shall hold meetings when necessary to promptly advise
the Mayor and/or Council. Such meetings shall be called by the Chairman at the
request of the Mayor or by the majority of Council. All meetings of the
Commission shall be conducted in accordance with Ohio ORC 121.22 “Open
Meetings,” and the Commission shall attempt to include an opportunity for the
public to address it.
(Ord. 4207. Passed 2-21-24.)

   149.01 HOLIDAYS.
   All full-time officers and employees of the Village shall be entitled to
thirteen paid holidays (or 104 paid holiday hours for 12-hour employees)
throughout the year as follows: January 1; Presidents Day; Martin Luther King
Day; Good Friday; Memorial Day; Juneteenth; July 4; First Monday in September;
Veterans Day; Thanksgiving Day; December 25th; and two days to be taken as
desired by the employee with the approval of the department head. No additional
holiday shall be given without the approval of Council. In addition, with the
approval of the Mayor and the appropriate department head, once a year in
December, a full-time employee may be paid in cash for up to five (5) unused
paid holidays of the thirteen (13) permitted in one year. (Ord. 4162. Passed
11-16-22.)
   149.02 VACATIONS.
   (a)   All full-time officers and employees of the Village shall be entitled
to ten days’ vacation (or eighty hours for 12-hour employees) with pay after
one full year from the starting date of employment and for each year of service
thereafter unless such full-time officer or employee’s starting date is on or
after July 1st. If said starting date is on or after July 1st, such full-time
officer or employee shall be entitled to five days (or forty hours for 12-hour
employees) with pay after one full year from the starting date of employment
and be increased to ten days (or eighty hours for 12-hour employees) annually
on January 1st of the following year. After completion of five full years of
continuous employment, full-time officers and employees shall receive the
following amount of vacation days/hour with pay:
   Years of Service      Amount of Vacation
   Five            Fifteen days (120 hours for 12-hour employees)
   Ten            Twenty days (160 hours for 12 hour employees)
   Fifteen         Twenty-five days (200 hours for 12 hour employees)
   Twenty-five         Thirty days (240 hours for 12 hour employees)
   (b)   All officers and employees shall receive credit for the continuous
service previous to the effective date of this section. The time for such
vacations shall be fixed by the Mayor, or in case he delegates the same, by the
head of the various departments, except that entitlement to vacation time may
not be carried over beyond the end of the applicable calendar year, unless
otherwise approved by the Mayor. (Ord. 4163. Passed 11-16-22.)   
   149.03 SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   All full-time employees of the Village shall be entitled for each
completed eighty hours of service to sick leave of four and six-tenths hours
with pay. Employees may use sick leave, upon written approval of the Mayor, or
under such other rules and regulations as he shall promulgate, for absence due
to personal illness, pregnancy, injury, exposure to contagious disease which
could be communicated to other employees, and for illness, injury or death in
the employee’s immediate family. Unused sick leave shall be cumulative without
limit. Provisional employees or those who render part-time, seasonal,
intermittent, per diem or hourly service shall be entitled to sick leave for
the time actually worked, at the same rate that is granted to full-time
employees.
   (b)   The Mayor may require an employee to furnish a satisfactory written,
signed statement to justify the use of sick leave. If medical attention is
required, a certificate stating the nature of the illness from a licensed
physician shall be required to justify the use of sick leave. Falsification of
either a written, signed statement or a physician’s certificate shall be
grounds for disciplinary action including dismissal.
   (c)   All full-time employees of the Village may elect, at the time of
retirement from active, full-time service with the Village and with ten or more
years of continuous service with the Village, the State or other political
subdivisions of the State, or any combination thereof, to be paid in cash for
one-half the value of his/her accrued but unused sick leave credit. The payment
shall be based on the employee’s rate of pay at the time of retirement and
eliminates all sick leave credit accrued but unused by the employee at the time
payment is made. An employee may receive one or more payments under this
section, but the aggregate value of accrued but unused sick leave credit that
is paid shall not exceed, for all payments, the value of seven hundred twenty
(720) hours of accrued but unused sick leave.
   (d)   This section only applies at the retirement of full-time Village
employees and shall not be deemed applicable to any removal or involuntary
resignation. As used in this section, “retirement” means disability or service
retirement under any state or municipal retirement system in this state.
   (e)   Bereavement Leave. In addition to the above sick leave, all full-time
employees shall be entitled to up to three continuous days, or twenty-four
hours, of bereavement leave upon the death of a member of the immediate family.
For purposes of this provision of this subsection, "immediate family" shall be
defined as the full-time employees' spouse, child, father, mother, mother-in-
law, father-in-law, brother, sister, grandparents and grandparents-in-law.
   The bereavement leave set forth herein is available irrespective of the
availability of accumulated sick leave, and shall not be used or considered in
calculating available sick leave, sick leave credit or any payments upon
retirement as set forth in subsection (c) above.
(Ord. 3891. Passed 11-16-16.)
   149.04 HOSPITALIZATION.
   In order to provide increased hospital, medical and surgical insurance,
effective April 1, 1996, at Village expense for the regular full-time employees
of the Village, and permanent part-time employees regularly scheduled for
thirty (30) or more hours per week, the Village Clerk and Treasurer are hereby
authorized and directed to pay from the General Fund of the Village the regular
monthly charges billed by the Village's insurance carrier for the benefit of
such employees, with said employees contributing fifteen percent (15%) of the
total cost of the insurance as a payroll deduction.
(Ord. 3812. Passed 4-15-15.)
   149.05 TELEPHONE OPERATORS, BOOKKEEPER, INSPECTORS. (REPEALED)

149.05 was repealed by Ordinance 3808, passed April 15, 2015.)
   149.06 MILEAGE.
   All Village officers and employees shall be reimbursed for duly authorized
travel on municipal business upon presentation and approval of a written
statement of all expenses incurred. Reimbursement for automobile travel shall
be at the current applicable Federal rate.
(Ord. 3592A. Passed 3-20-13.)
   149.07 INJURY LEAVE.
   (a)   When a full-time employee is injured in the line of duty, while
actually working for the Village, he shall be eligible for paid injury leave
not to exceed ninety calendar days which shall not be deducted from any other
accumulated compensated absence time, provided such employee files for Workers
Compensation and executes a waiver assigning to the Village those sums of money
such employee would ordinarily receive as weekly compensation as determined by
law for those number of weeks the employee receives benefits under this
provision.
   (b)   Eligibility for injury leave must be approved by that employee’s
department head and the Mayor within ten days of the processing of such
employee’s Workers Compensation claim through the appropriate Village officer
and such decision shall be reported by the Mayor to Council at Council’s next
regularly scheduled meeting. Eligibility and approval for injury leave shall be
based, in part, upon such employee’s Workers Compensation claim processed
through the appropriate Village office, and, if necessary, also based upon a
physical examination by a physician appointed by the Village resulting in the
physician’s certification that the employee is unable to work due to the
injury. The opinion of the designated physician shall govern whether the
employee is actually disabled or not, but shall not govern whether the injury
was duty related.
   (c)   If at the end of the ninety day period the employee is still disabled,
the injury leave may, at the Mayor’s discretion, be extended for an additional
ninety calendar day period, or any portion thereof. Such decision shall be made
at least ten days prior to the end of such period and such decision shall be
reported by the Mayor to Council at Council’s next regularly scheduled meeting.
   (d)   During injury leave, sick leave shall not be earned and accumulated
nor shall time- off for holidays occurring during leave be granted. Uniform
allowances shall continue to remain in effect during the term of any injury
leave.
(Ord. 2696. Passed 2-17-93.)
   149.08 LEAVE DONATION PROGRAM.
   Employees of the Village of Bratenahl may donate paid sick leave to a fellow
employee who is otherwise eligible to accrue and use sick leave. This section
applies to both full-time and part-time employees of the Village. The intent of
the leave donation program is to allow employees to voluntarily provide
assistance to their co-workers who are in critical need of leave due to serious
illness or injury of the employee or a member of the employee's immediate
family. The definition of immediate family as provided in rule 123:1-47-01 of
the Ohio Administrative Code shall apply for the leave donation program.
   (a)   An employee may receive donated leave, up to the number of hours the
employee is scheduled to work each pay period or as provided in paragraph (a)
(4) of this rule, if the employee who is to receive donated leave:
      (1)   Or a member of the employee's immediate family has a serious
illness or injury;
      (2)   Has no accrued leave;
      (3)   Has not been approved to receive other Village or state-paid
benefits; and
      (4)   Has applied for any paid leave, workers' compensation, or benefits
program for which the employee is eligible. An employee who has applied for
these programs may use donated leave to satisfy the waiting period for such
benefits, when applicable. After the waiting period, donated leave may be used
up to an amount equal to the benefit for which the employee applied, (e.g.,
seventy percent for disability leave benefits) while the employee's application
is pending approval.
   (b)   Employees may donate leave if the donating employee:
      (1)   Voluntarily elects to donate leave and does so with the
understanding that donated leave will not be returned;
      (2)   Donates a minimum of eight hours; and
      (3)   Retains a combined leave balance of at least eighty hours. Leave
shall be donated in the same manner in which it would otherwise be used.
   (c)   The leave donation program shall be administered on a pay period by
pay period basis. Employees using donated leave shall be considered in active
pay status and shall accrue leave and be entitled to any benefits to which they
would otherwise be entitled. Leave accrued by an employee while using donated
leave shall be used, if necessary, in the following pay period before
additional donated leave may be received. Donated leave shall not count toward
the probationary period of an employee who receives donated leave during his or
her probationary period. Donated leave shall be considered sick leave, but
shall never be converted into a cash benefit.
   (d)   Employees who wish to donate leave shall certify:
      (1)   The name of the employee for whom the donated leave is intended;
      (2)   The type of leave and number of hours to be donated;
      (3)   That the employee will have a minimum combined leave balance of at
least eighty hours; and
      (4)   That the leave is donated voluntarily and the employee understands
that the donated leave will not be returned.
   (e)   Department heads shall ensure that no employees are forced to donate
leave. Department heads shall respect an employee's right to privacy, however
department heads may, with the permission of the employee who is in need of
leave or a member of the employee's immediate family, inform employees of their
co-worker's critical need for leave. Department heads shall not directly
solicit leave donations from employees. The donation of leave shall occur on a
strictly voluntary basis.
      (Ord. 3454. Passed 9-16-09.)
   149.09 EMPLOYEE PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   (a)   All new or promoted employees are subject to a probationary period as
follows:
         Full time employee - one (1) year from date of appointment.
Part time, seasonal part time, or temporary part time employee - 1040 hours.
   
   During the employee's probationary period, the employee may be terminated
without cause. In the case of promotion, the employee may be placed back into
his former position if the Mayor considers the employee unsuitable for the
intended position.
   (b)   The Street Commissioner, with the approval of the Mayor, may extend
the probationary period for an additional six (6) months for a Service
Department Employee if warranted. During such additional six (6) months, the
employee's rate of pay will remain at the rate established for a probationary
employee.
(Ord. 3774. Passed 7-16-14.)
   149.10 EDUCATIONAL ACHIEVEMENT.
   (a)   Full time employees who already have achieved or achieve an
associate's degree from an accredited college shall receive an additional
seventy-five one hundredths percent (.75%) salary increase.
   (b)   Full time employees who already have achieved or achieve a bachelor's
degree from an accredited college shall receive an additional one and one half
percent (1.5%) salary increase. (Ord. 3779. Passed 8-20-14.)
   149.11 JURY DUTY.
   (a)   Full time employees are granted time away from work with pay for jury
duty service. A copy of the jury summons must be presented to the Mayor within
forty-eight (48) hours of receipt so ample time is provided to make scheduling
adjustments. Any hours spent attending jury duty shall be considered hours
worked for purposes of computing overtime, sick time, and vacation time.
   (b)   If an employee's jury duty pay or compensation during such leave of
absence is less than the employee's Village pay would have been for the same
period, the employee will be paid by the Village the difference in money
between the Village pay and the jury duty pay for such period.   
(Ord. 3813. Passed 4-15-15.)
   149.12 EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAM.
   (a)   All Village employees, both full and part time, are granted the right
to participate in the Village’s Employee Wellness Program at no cost to said
Employees. The Employee Wellness Program shall have the goals of disease
prevention, healthy lifestyle maintenance and treatment of chronic ailments.
The Employee Wellness Program may include, but not be limited to, the
following:
      (1)   Health education and coaching.
      (2)   Weight management/healthy eating.
      (3)   Therapeutic services.
      (4)   Financial wellness counseling.
      (5)   Smoking cessation.
      (6)   Leadership development/team building.
      (7)   Eldercare support.
   (b)   The initial cost of the Employee Wellness Program shall not exceed
$5,000 annually, unless otherwise determined by Council.
(Ord. 3865. Passed 3-16-16.)
   149.13 EMPLOYEE COLA PROGRAM.
   (a)   All Village employees, both full and part time, are hereby entitled to
the right to participate in the Village’s annual Cost of Living Adjustment
(COLA) Program at no cost to said employees.
   (b)   The COLA shall be based on the latest available consumer price index
for Northeast Ohio in the smallest geographic area as published by the Bureau
of Labor Statistics for the 4th Quarter.
   (c)   For the calendar year 2018, all said employees shall receive a one and
six-tenths percent (1.6%) COLA increase to their salary or hourly rate to be
paid with their regular payroll. In addition, for the calendar year 2020, all
said employees shall receive a one and six-tenths percent (1.6%) COLA increase
to their salary or hourly rate to be paid with their regular payroll.
   (d)   After the calendar year 2018, all said employees may receive a
percentage of their annual salary or hourly rate as paid above as determined by
Council, subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   Should CPI be negative during the specified period, a wage decrease
will not be applied; and
      (2)   Maximum COLA increase shall be no greater than two and five-tenths
percent (2.5%); and
      (3)   Total increase for all employees cannot total more than ten percent
(10%) of General Fund balance and will be adjusted to ten percent (10%) total
if greater; and
      (4)   COLA increase does not apply and will not be paid in any year if
prior year total Village revenue decreases by more than ten percent (10%); and
      (5)   COLA increase does not apply if budget/appropriations for affected
fiscal year increase by more than ten percent (10%) or should there be
extraordinary and unforeseen expenditures of more than one million dollars
($1,000,000).
         (Ord. 4055. Passed 12-18-19.)

   151.01 CREATION; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby created a Disaster Services Agency for the Village as an
agency for the government, to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from natural disaster or enemy attack. The Agency shall
consist of a Director and such additional members to be appointed by the Mayor.
All officers and employees of the Village are hereby declared to be members of
the organization, together with those volunteer forces appointed to aid them
during a disaster.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 4-18-78.)
   151.02 APPOINTMENT OF DIRECTOR; DUTIES.
   The Director of the Disaster Services Agency shall be appointed by the Mayor
and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. The Director shall coordinate the
organization, administration, planning and operations of the Village and all
local agencies for civil defense and disaster services subject to the direction
and control of the Mayor and as provided by statutes and rules and regulations
promulgated thereunder.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 4-18-78.)
   151.03 FUNCTIONS.
   The Disaster Services Agency shall perform such functions within the
Municipality as are prescribed in and authorized by Ohio R.C. Chapter 5915 and
the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, and in addition shall perform
such duties outside the corporate limits as are required pursuant to mutual aid
arrangements with any other political subdivision or with the countywide civil
defense or disaster services organizations. In performing duties pursuant to
this chapter, the Disaster Services Director shall cooperate with other
political subdivisions, with countywide civil defense or disaster service
organizations; with the State and with the Federal Government, through
appropriate channels, and with private agencies in all matters pertaining to
the civil defense or disaster service activities of the Village.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 4-18-78.)
   151.04 COMPENSATION.
   The Director and other disaster service personnel appointed or assigned as
herein provided may receive such compensation as may be specifically provided
for by Council.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 4-18-78.)
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
Chap.
161. Mayor's Court
CHAPTER 161
Mayor's Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any
prosecution for the violation of a Municipal ordinance, and has jurisdiction in
all criminal causes involving moving traffic violations occurring on State
highways located within the corporate limits, subject to the right of the
defendant to trial by jury and before an impartial magistrate.
   Ohio R.C. 2945.17 provides that an accused has a right to be tried by a jury
at any trial in any court for the violation of any Ohio statute or of any
Municipal ordinance, except in cases in which the penalty involved does not
exceed a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Ohio R.C. 2937.08 and
Criminal Rule 23(A) provide that if the court in which a defendant is charged
with an offense is not a court of record (the Mayor's Court), and the charge is
such that a right to a jury trial exists, such matter shall not be tried before
him and shall be transferred to a court of record in the County if the
defendant:
(a)    Does not waive his right to trial by jury in a serious offense case for
which the penalty established by law includes confinement for more than six
months, or
(b)    Demands a jury trial in a petty offense case in which the penalty
prescribed is a fine greater than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and/or
imprisonment for not more than six months. "Such demand must be in writing and
filed with the clerk of court not less than ten days prior to the date set for
trial, or on or before the third day following receipt of notice of the date
set for trial, whichever is later. Failure to demand a jury trial as provided
in this subdivision is a complete waiver of the right thereto."
   In Ward v. Village of Monroeville, Ohio, 93 S. Ct. 80 (1972), the United
States Supreme Court held that where the mayor before whom the defendant was
compelled to stand trial was responsible for municipal finances and the mayor's
court provided a substantial portion of municipal revenues, defendant was
denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial magistrate as guaranteed by
the due process clause of the United States Constitution.
   The Supreme Court of Ohio has adopted the "Ohio Traffic Rules" which
prescribe the procedure to be followed in the Mayor's Court in traffic cases.
Rule 9(A) thereof states the jury demand shall be made pursuant to Criminal
Rule 23 referred to above. Rule 9(B) sets forth the conditions under which the
Mayor may hear a traffic case incorporating therein the holding in Ward v.
Village of Monroeville as further interpreted in State, ex rel. Brockman v.
Procter, 35 Ohio St. 2d 79 (1973): "Where, in a mayor's court, a defendant is
entitled to a jury trial and a jury demand is made pursuant to Criminal Rule
23, the Mayor shall transfer the case pursuant to subdivision (C). If a jury
demand is not made pursuant to Criminal Rule 23, and (or?) the defendant waives
his right to jury trial in writing, a mayor may try the case if (l) his
compensation as a judge is not directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions, or (2) he is not the chief executive and administrative officer of
the municipality and as such responsible for the financial condition of the
municipality. Guilty and no contest pleas may be taken by any mayor including
mayors whose compensation as a judge is directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions and mayors who as chief executive and administrative officer of the
municipality are responsible for the financial condition of the municipality. "
   The procedure for transferring a case to a court of record is set forth in
Rule 9(C): "Where a transfer is required, the mayor's court shall make a
written order directing the defendant to appear at the transferee court,
continuing the same bail, if any, and making appearance before the transferee
court a condition of bail, if any. Upon transfer, the mayor's court shall
transmit to the clerk of the transferee court the ticket and all other papers
in the case, and any bail taken in the case. Upon receipt of such papers the
clerk of the transferee court shall set the case for trial and shall notify the
defendant by ordinary mail of his trial date."
   Rule 13 provides that a court shall establish a traffic violation bureau and
specifies certain restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of
fines to be accepted as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.
161.01    Clerk of Mayor's Court.
161.02    Powers and duties.
161.03    Compensation; oath and bond.
161.04    Deputy clerk.
161.05   Mayor’s Court Computer Administrator.
161.06   Administrative Deputy Clerk of Courts.
161.07    Chief Magistrate of Mayors Court.

Mayor's powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 1905.20 et seq.

Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
   161.01 CLERK OF MAYOR'S COURT.
   There is hereby established the position of Clerk of the Mayor's Court who
shall be appointed by the Mayor and who shall serve at the pleasure of the
Mayor.
(Ord. 2123. Passed 6-21-78.)
   161.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)    The Clerk shall have general powers to administer oaths, take
affidavits, power to issue and sign all writs, process, subpoenas and papers
issuing out of the court, and to attach the seal of the court thereto, and
power to approve all bonds, sureties, recognizances and undertakings fixed by
the Mayor, or by law. He shall file and safely keep all journals, records,
books and papers belonging or appertaining to the court, record its proceedings
and perform all other duties which the Mayor may prescribe, and keep a book
showing all receipts and disbursements, which shall be open for public
inspection at all times.
   (b)    The Clerk shall prepare and maintain a general index, a docket as
prescribed by the Mayor, and such other records as the Mayor requires, or as
required by law, all of which shall be the public records of the court.
   (c)    The Clerk shall receive and collect all costs, fees, fines,
penalties, bail and other moneys payable to the court or to any officer of the
court and issue receipts therefor, and shall each month disburse the same to
the proper persons or officers and take receipts therefor, provided that fines
received for the violation of State laws, subject to Ohio R.C. 3375.50 and
3375.53, shall be paid to the County treasury. Moneys deposited as security for
costs shall be retained pending the litigation. He shall keep a separate
account of all receipts and disbursements, which shall be a permanent public
record of the office, as required by the Bureau of Inspection and Supervision
of Public Offices, and on the expiration of his term such records shall be
delivered to his successor. He shall have other powers and duties as are
prescribed by the Mayor or otherwise provided by law.
(Ord. 2123. Passed 6-21-78.)
   161.03 COMPENSATION; OATH AND BOND.
   The Clerk shall receive such compensation as is provided by Council, which
shall be payable in the method and manner prescribed by Council. Before
entering upon the duties of the office, the Clerk shall give bond of not less
than one thousand dollars ($1,000), the actual amount to be determined by the
Mayor, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. The premium
shall be paid by the Village.
(Ord. 2123. Passed 6-21-78.)
   161.04 DEPUTY CLERKS.
   (a)    The Mayor may appoint such deputy clerks as he deems advisable, who
shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor, to perform the duties pertaining to
the office of Clerk. Deputy clerks shall be compensated out of the Village
treasury as Council may prescribe.
   (b)    Each deputy clerk shall take an oath of office before entering upon
his duties, and the Mayor may require any deputy clerk to give bond in the
amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his duties, and the premium shall be paid by the Village.
(Ord. 2123. Passed 6-21-78.)
   161.05 MAYOR'S COURT COMPUTER ADMINISTRATOR.
   The Mayor may appoint a Mayor's Court Computer Administrator who shall
perform all duties pertaining to the Court's electronic recording keeping
requirements. The Mayor's Court Computer Administrator shall report to the
Mayor and be compensated at a rate fixed from time to time by the Council and
authorized by ordinance.
(Ord. 3781. Passed 9-17-14.)
   161.06 ADMINISTRATIVE DEPUTY CLERK OF COURTS.
   The Mayor may appoint with confirmation by Council an Administrative Deputy
Clerk of Courts who shall perform all duties pertaining to court documentation
and records and shall serve as a court liaison between the Police Department,
other departments and the general public, as well as other duties as assigned
by the Clerk of Courts. The Administrative Deputy Clerk of Courts shall report
to the Clerk of Courts and be compensated at a rate fixed from time to time by
the Council and authorized by ordinance.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-18-15.)
 
   161.07 CHIEF MAGISTRATE OF MAYORS COURT.
   (a)   The position of Chief Magistrate of Mayor’s Court is hereby created.
   (b)   The Chief Magistrate of Mayor’s Court shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to confirmation by the Council, and shall act under the direction of
the Mayor.
   (c)   The Chief Magistrate of Mayor’s Court shall act as Magistrate of the
Court and have oversight of other Magistrates, schedule meetings with court
personnel and work with court personnel on scheduling of courts, ensure that
all court personnel receive the training mandated by the Ohio Supreme Court,
conduct an ongoing review of court policies and procedures, and perform any
other duties as determined by the Mayor.
   (d)   The Chief Magistrate of Mayor’s Court shall be compensated at a rate
fixed from time to time by the Council and authorized by ordinance.
(Ord. 4131. Passed 1-19-22.)
