   1105.01 TITLE.
   This Code is the "Land Planning and Zoning Code and Zone Plan of the Village
of Bratenahl", and is part of the Village Plan.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1105.02 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purpose of this Code, and the intent of Council in its adoption, is to
provide planning, standards, criteria, procedures, regulations and control for
the use of land in the Village, and the design, use, bulk, location and spacing
of buildings in order to most effectively, and to the fullest extent
permissible under its powers of home rule, insure and preserve the public
health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general welfare of the
inhabitants of the Village.
   Bounded entirely by the City of Cleveland and the Lake Erie shoreline, the
Village is incapable of geographic or territorial expansion. Although most of
the area of Cleveland, which surrounds the Village, is of nonresidential use
and character, because of its location within the metropolitan area, its
relationship to Lake Erie and the historical development of the community, the
Village has traditionally provided a unique residential environment affording a
wide choice of housing. The preservation and enhancement of this unique
residential setting and wide choice of housing opportunities, which is a
primary objective of the Village, is dependent upon the ability of the Village
to provide for the increasing costs of municipal services. The costs of these
services in the Village are met through real estate taxes, a municipal income
tax and through the Village's share of taxes levied upon the estates of its
deceased residents. Revenues from these sources as generated by the existing
development of the Village can no longer be relied upon to continue to defray
necessary and rapidly escalating Village expenses.
   The maintenance of the range of housing choices and the quality of the
Village as a residential community is established by the Village as the primary
goal for the future. To achieve this goal, the Village recognizes that new
development shall occur to renew and further expand housing choices within the
community and to provide the basis for meeting the increasing financial
requirements of municipal services.
   The officials of the Village have recognized that revisions and adjustments
to this existing Zoning Code are necessary for the Village to respond to
changes in development economics and techniques and market preferences.
   Therefore, after careful study, the legislative authority has adopted, with
the approval of the Planning Commission, an Updated Master Plan and Development
Policy. To carry out the Plan and Development Policy and to preserve and
protect the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general
welfare of the Village and its inhabitants, and to preserve the essential
residential values of the Village, the legislative authority of the Village has
adopted and enacted this Code setting forth standards, criteria, procedures,
regulations and controls for the use of land in the Village and the design,
use, bulk, location and spacing of buildings thereon which shall most
effectively utilize the highest professional skills and provide the maximum
flexibility of design, arrangements, spacing and construction of improvements
on the land, and the location and character of such uses and buildings and the
increase and distribution of populations resulting therefrom.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1105.03 CONFLICT.
   Where a provision of this Code is found to be in conflict with any other
code or ordinance, or provision thereof, of the Village, such provision of this
Code shall prevail and be controlling.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1105.04 VALIDITY.
   Should any section or provision of this Code be declared invalid by a court
of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the
Code as a whole, or any part thereof, other than the section or provision so
declared to be invalid. Nor shall the decision affect its application to
different facts or circumstances.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1105.05 FORM OF CODE.
   This Code is subdivided by titles. Each title is subdivided by chapters.
Each chapter is subdivided into sections which are numbered in sequence within
the chapter, commencing with the first section in Chapter
1105, which section is numbered
1105.01. The first figure before the decimal signifies the chapter and the two
figures "01" after the decimal signify the first section in that chapter. The
title and chapter headings herein have been inserted for convenience in
reference and are not intended to define or limit the scope of, or otherwise
affect, any provision in this Code.
(Ord 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1105.06 ILLUSTRATIONS; VISUAL INTERPRETATION.
   Illustrations, prototype or concept plans which Council may approve and
append to this Code from time to time are intended to clarify, supplement and
be applied along with the land planning and architectural design criteria to
fulfill the intent, purposes and objectives of this Code.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1105.07 COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
   (a)   No structure shall be located, erected, constructed, reconstructed,
moved, converted, or enlarged; nor shall any structure or land be used or be
designed to be used, nor shall any land be subdivided within the limits of the
Village except in full compliance with all the provisions of this Planning and
Zoning Code and, when required, after the lawful issuance of the certificates
(s) or permit(s) required by this Code.
   (b)   Existing lots, buildings, structures and uses of land that do not
comply with the regulations of this Planning and Zoning Code are subject to the
regulations set forth in Chapter
1129, Nonconformance.
   (c)   No lot, setback, open space, or other space shall be reduced in area
or dimensions so as to make such area or dimension less than the minimum
required by this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (d)   No part of a setback, open space or other space provided for any
building or structure for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this
Code shall be included as part of a required setback, open space or other space
required under this Code for another building or structure not on the same lot.
(Ord. 4110. Passed 9-22-21.)

   1107.01 DEFINITION OF VILLAGE PLAN.
   The Village Plan of the Village of Bratenahl is the Updated Master Plan and
Development Policy, the Land Planning and Zoning Code and the Zone Plan or
Zoning Map, the Regional Dwelling House Code, the Plan of Major Streets and
Public Grounds and the Regional Building Code, together with all amendments
thereto adopted by Council.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1107.02 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   Each part of the Village Plan may be adopted separately. Each part shall be
in force and effect on the earliest effective date of the ordinance adopting
such part, although other parts of the plan may not be adopted.
(Ord. 1603. Passed 9-19-62.)
   1107.03 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No plat of land, subdivision thereof, construction or layout of streets,
public ways or private roads, installation of sewers, water mains or other
utilities, construction or alteration of buildings, or use of land shall be
approved unless the same complies fully with the requirements of the Village
Plan.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)

are authorized to attach their signatures to such map certifying to the
approval of the same by Council.
(Ord. 1591. Passed 5-16-62.)

   1111.01 RULE OF INTERPRETATION.
   Words used in this Code are used in their ordinary English usage. Certain
terms and words are herein defined and whenever used in this Code, they shall
have the meaning indicated in this chapter, except where the context indicates
a clearly different meaning.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.02 GENERAL TERMS.
   (a)    The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for", "designed for",
"intended for", "maintained for" or "occupied for".
   (b)    All words used in the singular shall include the plural, and all
words used in the present tense shall include the future tense, unless the
context clearly indicates the contrary.
   (c)    "County" means County of Cuyahoga, Ohio.
   (d)    "Village" means the Village of Bratenahl, Ohio.
   (e)    "Commission" means the Planning Commission of the Village of
Bratenahl, Ohio.
   (f)    "Council" means the legislative body of the Village of Bratenahl.
   (g)    "Board" means the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (h)    "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Buildings of the Village of
Bratenahl.
   (i)    "Clerk" means the duly acting and qualified Clerk of the Village of
Bratenahl.
   (j)   "Person" includes an individual, firm, association, corporation,
trust, or any other legal entity, including his or its agents.
   (k)    "Developer" means a person commencing proceedings under this Code to
effect a subdivision or development of land for himself or for another.
   (l)    "Code" means the Land Planning and Zoning Code.
   (m)    "Regulation" means a rule, restriction or other mandatory provision
in this Code intended to control, require or prohibit an act.
   (n)    "Standard" means a test, measure, model or example of quantity,
extent or quality.
   (o)    "Criterion" means a principle by which the planning of a subdivision
or development area shall be guided.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   (p)    "Occupant", for purposes of residential uses, shall mean any person
over one year of age who lives, sleeps, cooks or eats in, or has actual
possession of, a dwelling unit used for such purpose for a period of thirty
days or longer.
(Ord. 2682. Passed 1-20-93.)
   1111.03 GARAGES.
   (a)    “Private garage” means a detached building accessory to an individual
one-family dwelling or an individual two-family dwelling, or portion of the
dwelling (also known as an attached garage), used exclusively for the parking
or temporary storage of passenger automobiles, and other incidental personal
possessions.
   (b)    “Storage garage” means a structure, accessory to one or more town
houses or multi-family dwellings, used for the parking or temporary storage of
passenger automobiles and such other uses as may be permitted, and which may be
attached or detached to the residential structure.
   (c)    “Recreational Vehicle” means a vehicle primarily designated for
recreational use, which either has its own motive power or is mounted on or
drawn by another vehicle. Recreational vehicle includes but is not limited to,
recreational camping vehicles, folding tent trailer, boats, off highway
vehicles such as snowmobiles, motorcycles not licensed for use on public
streets, and any trailer that may be used to convey such a vehicle.
(Ord. 4227. Passed 12-28-24.)
 
   1111.04 BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES.
   (a)    "Structure" means that which is constructed on or under the ground or
attached or connected thereto, including but not limited to barriers, bridges,
buildings, streets, parking areas, bulkheads, chimneys, fences, poles, pools,
sheds, signs, garages, tanks, towers, transformer substations and walls.
   (b)    "Building" means a structure which is permanently affixed to the
land, having one or more floors and a roof, being bounded by either open spaces
or lot lines, and used as a shelter for persons, or enclosure for property. The
word shall be construed as if followed by the words "part or parts thereof".
   (c)    "Main building" means the building occupied by the main use or
activity on, or intended for the premises, all parts of which building are
connected in a substantial manner by walls and a continuous roof.
   (d)    "Accessory building" means a subordinate building detached from, but
located on the same lot as the main building, the use of which is incident and
accessory to that of the main building or use.
   (e)    "Area of building" means the area at the ground level of the main
building and all accessory buildings (excluding open porches, terraces and
steps) measured from the outside surface of exterior walls.
   (f)    "Land coverage" means that percentage of a lot or development area
covered by the main and accessory buildings.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   (g)    "Accessory recreational structure" means any paved or improved
recreational area, including but not limited to a private swimming or wading
pool, tennis, basketball, handball, racquet or similar court, or any other area
used for similar active recreational purposes.
(Ord. 2683. Passed 1-20-93.)
   (h)   “Building envelope” means the three-dimensional space encircling the
entire footprint and volume of the building.
(Ord. 4111. Passed 9-22-21.)
 
   1111.05 FAMILY.
   “Family” means either an individual, two or more persons related by blood,
marriage, adoption, or foster children, plus not more than two additional
persons not related as set forth above, or not more than four unrelated
individuals occupying a dwelling unit as their primary place of residence. In
each situation, all members of such family are living together as a single
housekeeping unit.
(Ord. 4111. Passed 9-22-21.)
   1111.06 DWELLINGS AND OTHER LIVING ACCOMMODATIONS.
   (a)    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms in a dwelling which are
arranged, designed, used or intended for occupancy by one family maintaining a
common household, and which includes lawful cooking space and lawful sanitary
facilities reserved for the occupants thereof.
   (b)    "Dwelling" means a building which is arranged, designed, used or
intended exclusively for residential use and permitted accessory uses.
   (c)   “One-family dwelling” means a dwelling consisting of a single dwelling
unit with the main entrance to its living quarters at ground level; entirely
surrounded by open space and detached from any other dwelling.
   (d)    "Two-family dwelling" means a dwelling consisting of two separate
dwelling units attached either vertically or horizontally.
   (e)    "Townhouse" means a one-family dwelling which is part of a sequence
of three or more one-family dwellings, attached by a common fireproof wall or
walls and arranged in one building of any shape, determined by an approved
plan.
   (f)    "Multi-family dwelling" means a dwelling, other than a townhouse,
containing three or more dwelling units on the same lot with the number of
families not exceeding the number of dwelling units permitted in the zoning
district, as determined by an approved plan.
(Ord. 4219. Passed 6-19-24.)
   1111.07 GRADES.
   (a)    "Established street grade" means the elevation established by the
Village at the roadway centerline.
   (b)    "Natural grade" means the elevation of the undisturbed natural
surface of the ground prior to any excavation or fill.
 
   (c)   “Finished grade” means the elevation of the finished surface of the
ground adjoining the building after final grading and normal settlement.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.08 HEIGHT OF BUILDING.
   “Height of building” means the vertical distance measured from the highest
point of the coping of a flat roof, or the vertical distance measured from the
mean level between the eaves and ridge of a pitched roof to the average
finished grade across the face of the building containing its principal
entrance.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.09 LOT; PARCEL.
   (a)   “Lot” means a tract of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a
use, building or group of buildings, their accessory uses and buildings as a
unit, and associated open spaces, the extent of which development rights are
calculated and the basis of such calculations.
   (b)   “Unplatted lot or parcel” means a lot or parcel of land which has not
been made a part of a recorded plat filled in the office of the Cuyahoga County
Recorder.
   (c)   “Lot of record” means land designated as a separate lot or parcel on a
plat, map or deed in the records of Cuyahoga County, Ohio for purposes of sale,
lease, purchase, agreement or separate use.
   (d)   “Parcel,” see “Lot,”
   (e)   “Area of lot or parcel” means the total horizontal area within the lot
lines of a lot or parcel. The water’s edge of Lake Erie, as delineated on the
Village Topographic Map prepared by the Cuyahoga County Engineer which is on
file with the Village Clerk, shall be deemed a lot line.
   (f)   “Corner lot” means a lot abutting on two streets at their
intersections, where the interior angle of intersection is not more than 135
degrees.
   (g)   “Interior lot” means a lot other than a corner lot.
   (h)   “Lot line” means the boundary of a lot separating it from a public
street or adjoining public or private land.
   (i)   “Front lot line” means a lot line separating a lot from a street
right-of-way on which the lot fronts. Where a lot is located at the
intersection of two or more streets, there shall be a front lot line on each
street side of a corner lot. Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary,
the term front lot line is synonymous with street line.
   (j)   “Rear lot line” means a lot line parallel or within forty-five degrees
of being parallel to the front lot line. For corner lots where there is a front
lot line on each street side, there shall be no rear lot line.
   (k)   “Side lot line” means a lot line which is neither a front nor a rear
lot line. For corner lots, there shall be two side lot lines.
   (l)   “Building setback line” means a line established by this Code
generally parallel with and measured from the street line or property line,
defining the limits of the required yard in which no building, or structure may
be located above ground, except as may be specifically allowed.
   (m)   “Street line” means the street right-of-way line.
   (n)   “Private land” means land in a subdivision or development area which
shall be adjoining, attached and assigned to a one-family dwelling, to be held
as an open space in ownership with the dwelling, and which shall be identified
on all plans submitted to the Village regardless of the type or kind of
development.
   (o)   “Common land” means land in a development area not owned as private
land or occupied by dwellings, and which is held for the use and benefit in
common by or for the owners or occupants of the dwellings in the development
area, including interest and rights in private land in such development area
which are created for common usage by restrictions, easements, covenants or
other conditions running with the land.
   (p)   “Development area” means the minimum area of land permitted by this
Code to be developed by a single owner or a group of owners, acting jointly,
which may consist of a parcel or assembled parcels, and include a related group
of one-family dwellings, town houses or multi-family dwellings planned and
developed as an entity.
   (q)   “Pedestrian way” means a public or private right of way limited to
pedestrian traffic.
   (r)   “Easement” means the right of a person to use common land or private
land owned by another for a specific purpose.
   (s)   “Drainage way” means the land required for construction of storm water
sewers or drainage ditches, or required along a natural stream or watercourse.
(Ord. 4111. Passed 9-22-21.)
 
   1111.10 MAPS, PLANS, PLATS.
   (a)   “Map” means a drawing showing geographic, topographic or other
physical features of the land.
   (b)   “Plan” means a drawing of a proposed design or of work to be
performed.
   (c)   “Plat” means a map of a lot, subdivision or development area on which
the lines of each element are shown by accurate distances and bearings.
 
   (d)   “Preliminary plan” means a preliminary plan of a subdivision or
development area which may include explanatory exhibits and text, submitted to
the designated authority for the purpose of study of a subdivision or
development area and which, when approved, provides the basis for proceeding
with the preparation of the final plat of a subdivision or final plan of a
development area.
   (e)   “Final plan of a development area” means a final plan based on the
approved preliminary plan of a development area and consists of detailed
drawings, specifications, cost estimates, and agreements for the construction
of the site improvements and buildings within a development area.
   (f)   “Final plat” means the plat showing the various divisions of land of a
final subdivision plan or final plan of a development area and, when approved,
authorized to be recorded.
(Ord .2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1111.11 NONCONFORMING STRUCTURE, LOT AND USE.
   (a)   “Nonconforming structure” means a structure, existing lawfully at the
time this Code, or an amendment thereto, became effective but which does not
conform to the area, height or bulk of building or yard regulations of the
district in which it is located.
   (b)   “Nonconforming lot” means a lot, existing lawfully at the time that
this Code, or an amendment thereto became effective, but which does not conform
to the lot area, width or access requirements of the district in which it is
located.
   (c)   “Nonconforming use” means the use of a structure or land, existing
lawfully at the time this Code or an amendment thereto became effective, but
which does not conform to the use regulations of the district in which it is
located.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.12 OCCUPANCY PERMIT.
   (a)   “Occupancy permit” means an official permit asserting that a given
building, other structure or parcel of land, is in compliance with the
provisions of all applicable codes, or is a lawfully existing nonconforming
building or use and hence may be occupied and used lawfully for the purposes
designated thereon.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.13 PUBLIC NOTICE.
   “Public notice” means at least ten days’ notice of the time and place of
hearing to be held by the Planning Commission or the Board of Zoning Appeals
which, as determined by Council, shall be either printed in a newspaper of
general circulation in the Village, or posted in not less than three public
places in the Village.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1111.14 SIGNS.
   (a) "Sign" means any display, figure, painting, drawing, placard, poster or
other device visible from a public way which is designed, intended or used to
convey a message, advertise, inform or direct attention to a person,
institution, organization, activity, place, object or product.
   (b)   "Business sign" means a sign erected, maintained or used for the
purpose of the display of messages appurtenant to the use of, products sold on,
or the sale or lease of, or other activity conducted on the property on which
it is displayed, or for a noncommercial message, on a lot in an O or NC
District, which sign may be permitted only as an accessory use located on such
premises. Also known as an on-premise sign.
   (c)   “Off-Premise Sign” means a sign whose message directs attention to a
specific business, product, service, entertainment event or activity, or other
commercial activity, or other message about something that is not sold,
produced, manufactured, furnished, or conducted at the property upon which the
sign is located, and which may be used from time-to-time to display a
noncommercial message. Also known as an outdoor advertising sign.
   (d)   “Noncommercial Sign” means a sign with a message that conveys a
noncommercial message and does not propose or promote a commercial transaction
or direct attention to a good, product, commodity, business, service, event, or
other object that serves as the basis of a commercial transaction.
   (e)   “Billboard” means an off-premise sign that exceeds 240 square feet.
(Ord. 4088. Passed 3-17-21.)
   1111.15 STREETS.
   "Street" means a way for vehicular traffic dedicated to public use which
shall be deemed to include the entire area within the right of way. The term
includes, but is not necessarily limited to, avenue, boulevard, drive, highway,
road and freeway. Streets shall be classified and further defined as follows:
(a)    "Freeway" means a divided arterial highway for through traffic to which
access from the abutting properties is prohibited.
(b)    "Major street" means a public street which is primarily for moving fast
or heavy traffic between large or intensively developed districts.
(c)    "Secondary or collector street" means a street supplementary to and
connecting major streets to local streets.
(d)   "Local street" means a street primarily for access to abutting
residential properties and to serve local needs.
(1)    "Cul-de-sac" means a street, one end of which connects with another
street and the other end of which is a dead end which provides turning
facilities for vehicles.
(2)    "Marginal access street" means a local street providing access to lots
which abut or are adjacent to a limited-access highway or major street.
(e)    "Parkway" means a roadway running through a strip of public park land to
which right of access may or may not be prohibited.
(f)    "Right-of-way" means all of the land included within an area which is
dedicated, reserved by deed, or granted by easement for street purposes.
(1)    "Roadway" means that portion of a right-of-way available for vehicular
traffic, including parking lanes.
(2)    "Tree lawn" means that portion of a right-of-way lying between the
exterior line of the roadway and the outside right-of-way line.
(3)    "Sidewalk" means that portion of a tree lawn developed for a pedestrian
walkway.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1111.16 PRIVATE WAYS.
   “Private way” means a way for vehicular passage held in private ownership
within a planned residential development area which provides access from
streets into the planned residential development area and which provides for
the circulation and movement of vehicles within the area and access to parking
and garage areas serving the residential units within the area.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1111.17 USE.
   (a)   “Use” means any purpose for which buildings, other structures or land
may be arranged, designed, maintained or occupied or any activity carried on in
a building or other structure or on land.
   (b)   “Main use” means the principal use of, or activity in a building or
other structure, or the principal activity on land.
   (c)   “Accessory use” means a use which is subordinate, incidental and
related to that of a main building or main use of the land and on the same lot.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   1111.18 YARDS.
   (a)   “Yard” means that portion of the open area on a lot extending between
a building and the lot line or between an accessory use of a building requiring
a yard, in this Code, and the lot line.
   (b)   “Front yard” means the yard extending from the face of the building to
the front lot line and extending across the full width of the lot.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
   (c)   “Rear yard” means the yard extending from the rear wall of the
building to the rear lot line across the full width of the lot. For corner lots
where there is a front yard on each street side, there shall be no rear yard.
 
   (d)   “Side yard” means the yard extending between a side lot line and the
nearest wall of the building and from the front yard to the rear yard; except
for corner lots, where the side yard is measured from the nearest front yard to
the adjacent side lot line.
(Ord. 3071. Passed 7-18-01.)
   (e)   “Required yard” means the minimum yard required between a lot line and
a main building line, or between a lot line and the line of accessory use or
building, requiring a yard in order to comply with the regulations of the
district in which the lot is located. A required yard shall be open and
unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except for projections on buildings as
permitted in this Code and except for landscaping and yard features.
   (f)   “Court” means an open space, other than a yard, bounded on two or more
sides by exterior walls of a building.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)

CHAPTER 1115
Planning Commission
1115.01   Membership; terms.
1115.02   Officers; rules.
1115.03   Quorum.
1115.04   Powers.
1115.05   Council to approve rules.

CROSS REFERENCES
Establishing a planning commission - see Ohio R.C. 713.01
Powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 713.02, 713.06
Planning Commission to be Platting Commission - see Ohio R.C. 713.03
   1115.01 MEMBERSHIP; TERMS.
   (a)   There is established a Planning Commission of five members consisting
of the Mayor, one member of Council to be elected thereby for the remainder of
his term as such Council member, and three citizens of the Village to be
appointed by the Mayor for terms of six years each, excepting that Council and
citizen members of the Commission, holding office as Commission members on the
date of the enactment of this Code, shall continue as members of the Planning
Commission herein established for the remainder of their terms of original
appointment.
   (b)   There shall be appointed two alternate members who are resident
freeholders appointed by the Mayor and approved by Council. In the event a
regular member is absent for any reason or has a conflict of interest with
respect to a proposed project under review, an alternate member shall be
designated by the Chairman of the Commission to serve during such absence or
such conflict of interest. When serving in the place of a regular member of the
Commission, an alternate member shall have the same powers and perform the same
duties as a regular member of the Commission. (Ord. 4082. Passed 7-15-20.)
   1115.02 OFFICERS; RULES.
   The Planning Commission shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman from its
members and a secretary who may, or may not, be a member. It shall adopt rules
or by-laws for the holding of regular and special meetings, the transaction and
disposition of its business and the exercise of its powers. Where either the
general laws of Ohio, or Council by ordinance, have provided for the manner of
the exercise of the powers of the Commission, such procedure shall be followed.

(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.03 QUORUM.
   All meetings of the Planning Commission shall be public. A majority of its
members shall constitute a quorum at any meeting. No action of the Commission
shall be deemed taken unless concurred in by a majority of its members.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.04 POWERS.
   The Planning Commission shall have such powers as are conferred by the
general laws of Ohio or by ordinance of Council.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.05 COUNCIL TO APPROVE RULES.
   No rules or regulation of the Planning Commission, other than those
authorized in Section
1115.02, shall become effective until the rule or regulation has been approved,
after public hearing, by Council.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.06 EMPLOYMENT OF ARCHITECTS AND ENGINEERS.
   The Planning Commission may control, appoint or employ professional
services, and may appoint a secretary, clerks, draftsmen and other subordinates
as it finds necessary in connection with the performance of its functions and
duties. Expenditures for such service and employment shall be within the amount
appropriated for such purpose by Council.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.07 ACCESS TO PROPERTY.
   For the purpose of making necessary surveys, engineers, agents and
representatives of the Planning Commission may enter upon all property within
the limits of the Village. Such agents and representatives of the Commission
shall have access to all property in making any survey in connection with any
matter being considered by the Commission.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
   1115.08 COMMISSION TO APPROVE PUBLIC BUILDINGS.
   No public building or structure, street, park, playground, public ground,
bridge, dock or other public way, ground, works or utility, whether publicly or
privately owned, or a part thereof, shall be constructed or authorized to be
constructed within the limits of the Village unless the location, character and
extent thereof is approved by the Planning Commission. In case of disapproval,
the Commission shall communicate its reasons therefor to Council and to the
head of the department which has control of the construction of the proposed
improvement or utility. Council, by a vote of not less than two-thirds of its
members and of such department head, together may overrule such disapproval. If
such public way, ground, works, building, structure or utility is one the
authorization or financing of which does not, under the law, fall within the
province of Council, the submission to the Commission shall be by the state,
school, county, district, board, commission or body having jurisdiction and the
Commission’s disapproval may be overruled by such official board, commission or
body by a vote of not less than two thirds of its membership. The narrowing,
ornamentation, vacation or change in the use of streets and other public ways,
grounds and places, shall be subject to similar approval, and this approval may
be similarly overruled.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
CHAPTER 1117
Architectural and Design Review Board
1117.01   Establishment of Architectural and Design Review Board.
1117.02   Officers.
1117.03   Alternate members.
1117.04   Qualifications.
1117.05   Removal of members.
1117.06   Meetings and compensation.
1117.07   Powers and duties.
1117.08   Design review criteria.
   1117.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF ARCHITECTURAL AND DESIGN REVIEW BOARD.
   There is hereby established an Architectural and Design Review Board
consisting of three regular members having the qualifications provided in
Section
1117.04, to be appointed by the Mayor and approved by Council prior to the
effectiveness of the appointment. Regular members shall be appointed for terms
of three years ending December 31 in each year. For the initial appointments,
one member shall be appointed to a one-year term, one member to a two-year
term, and one member to a three-year term. A vacancy shall be filled for the
unexpired term.
(Ord. 3402. Passed 4-16-08.)
   1117.02 OFFICERS.
   One regular member of the Board shall be elected Chair and shall be
responsible for the proper administration of the Board’s duties. One regular
member shall act as Secretary to keep a complete record of all meetings of the
Board.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
   1117.03 ALTERNATE MEMBERS.
There shall be appointed three alternate members having the qualifications set
forth in Section
1117.04. In the event a regular member is absent for any reason or has a
conflict of interest with respect to a proposed project under review, an
alternate member shall be designated by the Chairman of the Board to serve
during such absence or such conflict of interest. When serving in the place of
a regular member of the Board, an alternate member shall have the same powers
and perform the same duties as a regular member of the Board.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
   1117.04 QUALIFICATIONS.
   At least two of the regular members and at least two of the alternate
members of the Architectural and Design Review Board shall be registered
architects in the state. The other regular and alternate member may be a
registered landscape architect or a registered architect. Each regular member
must have been actively engaged in the practice of his/her profession in the
state for a period of not less than five years prior to his/her appointment to
the Board.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
 
   1117.05 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   Any member of the Architectural and Design Review Board shall be subject to
removal from such membership for cause in the manner provided for by the
statutes of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
 
   1117.06 MEETINGS AND COMPENSATION.
   The Architectural and Design Review Board shall establish a regular time for
monthly meetings. Additional meetings may be called by the Chair, if needed.
The Board, by motion, has the right to adopt rules and operating procedures for
conducting its meetings. Compensation shall be paid each member of the
Architectural and Design Review Board as is fixed by Council.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
 
   1117.07 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the Architectural and Design Review Board are as
follows:
   (a)    To assist and advise the Planning Commission in reviewing development
plans for:
      (1)    Nonresidential uses and business signs in the R-LF, R-1, R-2, R-3,
and R-4 Districts, as permitted in Section
1155.02(b), which shall be reviewed pursuant to the procedures set forth in
Section
1153.08;
      (2)    All uses and business signs in an O District, as permitted in
Sections
1159.02 through
1159.04, which shall be reviewed pursuant to the procedures set forth in
Section
1153.08;
      (3)    All nonresidential uses, townhouses and multi-family dwellings in
an NC District, as permitted in Section
1161.02, which shall be reviewed pursuant to the procedures set forth in
Section
1153.08; and
      (4)   Planned residential developments, as permitted in Chapter
1162, which shall be reviewed pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section
1164.14.
   (b)    To advise the Planning Commission in reviewing the final
architectural design of a dwelling within a planned residential development in
accordance with the procedures set forth in Section
1164.14.
   (c)    To review and act upon applications for the construction of single-
family dwellings, the construction of two-family dwellings in a NC District,
the addition of certain accessory structures, or changes to the footprint or
ground floor area of existing single-family dwellings and existing two-family
dwellings where permitted, as specified in Schedule
1154.03 and in accordance with the procedures set forth in Section
1154.04.
   (d)    To review and act upon an application to modify the building envelope
of an existing single-family dwelling or existing two-family dwelling, such as
adding bay windows, dormers, and/or modifying the roof pitch, or add certain
accessory structures, as specified in Schedule
1154.03 and in accordance with the procedures set forth in Section
1154.05.
   (e)    To review fence applications pursuant to Chapter
1171.
   The design review criteria set forth in Section
1117.08, and all other standards, regulations and criteria contained in this
Code, shall be considered by the Architectural and Design Review Board in its
review. (Ord. 4228. Passed 12-18-24.)
 
   1117.08 DESIGN REVIEW CRITERIA.
   The following criteria shall be utilized in reviewing applications subject
to design review, to assure that the purposes and intent of this Zoning Code
are satisfied.
(a)   The proposal shall be consistent with the relevant purposes, objectives
and related development policies set forth in any applicable plans or other
documents prepared for and/or by the Village.
(b)   The orientation of any proposed construction shall be reasonably
integrated with existing roads, driveways and pedestrian walkways abutting the
property on which the proposed construction is to be built.
(c)   The design and location of the buildings on the site shall be of a scale
to complement adjacent buildings and enhance the character of the surrounding
area with features that are appropriate and compatible with existing buildings
and structures. In making this determination, the following items shall be
considered:
(1)   Building height, width and general proportions;
(2)   The historic context in which the dwelling, the surrounding areas and the
Village were developed.
(3)   Architectural features, including patterns of windows and doors, rood
pitch, cornice lines, balconies, porches, shutters, dormers, eaves and other
decorative detail; and
(4)   Colors.
(d)    Materials used in the proposed construction or alterations should be
compatible with, and not in sharp contrast to, the existing building and/or
materials used on adjacent structures.
(e)    The proposal should minimize changes to the natural grade, and the
removal and destruction of trees, landscaping or other natural features;
(f)   Proposed alterations to significant architectural features should closely
match the original material in composition, design, color, texture and all
other visual qualities.
(g)   The removal of distinguishing qualities or character of a building or
property that contribute to the overall character of the Village should be
avoided.
(h)   Proposed construction should be oriented on the site to maintain
reasonable light and air and privacy.
(i)    Architectural details and ornamentation should be meaningful to the
overall design and appropriate for the size and scale of proposed structures,
and harmonious with other architectural detail and ornamentation on adjacent
property.
   In addition to the above criteria, the Architectural and Design Review Board
and/or the Planning Commission may, from to time, promulgate supplemental
illustrations and utilize the designs of existing historical structures to
guide the applicants, Board and Commission in interpreting the criteria herein
in carrying out the intent of this Zoning Code.
(Ord. 3050. Passed 1-17-01.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1119
Amendments
 
1119.01   Changes to be considered by Planning Commission.
1119.02   Filing Commission report with Council.
1119.03   Mandatory hearing.
1119.04   Notice of hearing.
1119.05   Voting.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Council may amend districting or zoning - see Ohio R.C. 713.10
 
   1119.01 CHANGES TO BE CONSIDERED BY PLANNING COMMISSION.
   Council, either on petition of a property owner or on its own initiative,
may amend or change the number, shape, area or regulations of or within any
zone or district, but no such amendment or change shall become effective unless
the proposed amendment or change is first submitted to or considered by the
Planning Commission for its approval, disapproval or suggestions. The
Commission shall be allowed a reasonable time, to be not less than thirty days
after referral or submittal, for consideration and report.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1119.02 FILING COMMISSION REPORT WITH COUNCIL.
   It shall be the duty of the secretary of the Planning Commission to
forthwith file with the Clerk of Council a report of the action and suggestions
of the Commission with respect to any referral or submittal. Failure to file
such report within thirty days after referral or the time otherwise provided,
shall be accepted as and be deemed an approval of the proposed change or
amendment submitted.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1119.03 MANDATORY HEARING.
   Before any ordinance, measure or regulation amending or changing the number,
shape, area or regulations of or within any zone or district may be passed,
Council shall hold a public hearing thereon. It shall give thirty days notice
of the time and place thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the
Village. During such thirty days the text or copy of the text of such
ordinance, measure, regulation or proposed change, together with the maps or
plans or copies thereof forming part of or referred to in such ordinance,
measure, regulation or proposed change, and the maps, plans and reports
submitted by the Planning Commission, shall be on file for public examination
in the office of the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1119.04 NOTICE OF HEARING.
   If the ordinance, measure, change or regulation intends to re-zone or re-
district ten or less parcels of land as listed on the tax duplicate, written
notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the Clerk, by first class mail, at
least twenty days before the date of public hearing to the owners of property
within and contiguous to and directly across the street from such parcel or
parcels to the addresses of such owners appearing on the County Auditor’s
current tax list or the Treasurer’s mailing list and to such other list or
lists that may be specified by Council. The failure of delivery of such notice
shall not invalidate any such ordinance, measure, change or regulation.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1119.05 VOTING.
   No such ordinance, measure, regulation or proposed change which violates,
differs from or departs from the plans or report submitted by the Planning
Commission, shall take effect unless passed or approved by not less than three-
fourths of the membership of Council. Any such ordinance, measure or proposed
change may be amended by majority vote, prior to the voting thereon by Council,
without further notice or postponement if such amendment is germane to the
subject matter and does not violate, differ or depart from the report of the
Commission.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)

   1121.01 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   There is established the Board of Zoning Appeals of five members,
consisting of the Mayor, a Council member representative to be appointed by the
Council and three (3) resident freeholders appointed by the Mayor and approved
by Council prior to the effectiveness of the appointment for a term consisting
of two years commencing on January 1 of the even numbered years, but who shall
initially be appointed for a term ending December 31, 1963.
   (b)   There shall be appointed two alternate members who are resident
freeholders appointed by the Mayor and approved by Council. In the event a
regular member is absent for any reason or has a conflict of interest with
respect to a proposed project under review, an alternate member shall be
designated by the Chairman of the Board to serve during such absence or such
conflict of interest. When serving in the place of a regular member of the
Board, an alternate member shall have the same powers and perform the same
duties as a regular member of the Board. (Ord. 4067. Passed 5-20-20.)
   1121.02 FUNCTIONS.
   The functions of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be:
   (a)   To review and determine appeals from decisions of the Commissioner of
Buildings under this Code, except as otherwise specified in Section
1154.06 and Chapter
1171, or in the refusal of any permit.
   (b)   To interpret the provisions of this Code where there is doubt of its
meaning or application;
   (c)   To make variances in the application of the regulations, in cases of
practical difficulty and unnecessary hardship, which shall be confirmed by
Council before being effectual, except for adjustments and exceptions that fall
under the authority of the Architectural and Design Review Board as specified
in Chapter
1171. (Ord. 4112. Passed 9-22-21.)
 
   1121.03 MEETINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC; OFFICERS.
   All meetings of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be public. It shall keep
minutes of its proceedings. The Mayor shall be chairman of the Board and it
shall elect a secretary who shall keep the records and minutes of the Board and
perform such other duties as the Board shall delegate.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.04 RULES AND BY-LAWS.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall adopt, from time to time, such rules and
by-laws as it may deem necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this
Code and for the holding of regular or special meetings, the transaction of its
business and the exercise of its powers.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.05 QUORUM.
   A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of
business of the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.06 POWERS.
   The powers herein prescribed are to be exercised in accordance with the
provisions of this Code, and where the manner of exercise is not set forth by
the rules of the Board. All powers shall be strictly construed so that the
spirit of this Code is not violated.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.07 VARIANCES.
   Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship in the way of
carrying out the strict letter of the provisions of this Code, the Board of
Zoning Appeals shall have the power, in a specific case of a property owner, to
vary any such provisions in harmony with its general purpose and intent so that
the public safety, health, morals and general welfare may be secured and
substantial justice done.
   In granting such variance, the Board shall make it subject to such
appropriate conditions and safeguards as will, in the Board's opinion, protect
as far as reasonable the health, safety, attractiveness and value of adjoining
and surrounding property.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.08 INTERPRETATION OF CODE BY BOARD IF DOUBT ARISES.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals may interpret the application of the provisions
of this Code where there is doubt as to its meaning or application. If there
arises any misunderstanding in reference to the interpretation of any of the
uses, such misunderstanding shall constitute a special case and shall be left
to the discretion of the Board.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.09 PUBLIC HEARING PRIOR TO DECISION.
   Before determining any appeal or application, the Board of Zoning Appeals
shall give public notice and hold a public hearing.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.10 APPLICATION INFORMATION; NOTICE OF HEARING TO NEIGHBORS; FEE.
   Before any variance, interpretation or exception shall be considered, the
property owner shall file a written application therefor. It shall set forth
the location of the premises, the names and addresses of adjacent property
owners, a clear statement of the reasons in support thereof and such other
information as the Board of Zoning Appeals may require. The application shall
be open for public inspection. Application to the Board, as provided above,
shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable filing fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00).
   Upon filing of any application, and the required fee therewith, the Board
shall cause public notice thereof to be given and at least five days prior to
the public hearing and shall cause notice thereof to be sent by registered or
certified mail to all property owners as shown upon the County Auditor's
duplicate and within 300 feet of the land in question. Where such land is under
the same ownership, the owners of all property adjoining shall be notified.
Failure of delivery of such notice shall not invalidate the proceeding.
(Ord. 2077. Passed 5-18-77.)
 
   1121.11 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   The applicant or property owner may appeal to the Board from any decision of
the Commissioner of Buildings including his refusal to issue any permit. Notice
of appeal from the decision shall be filed with the Commissioner within ten
days after the decision. Within three days he shall file the notice of appeal
with all original papers and a transcript with the secretary or chairman of the
Board of Zoning Appeals. A hearing de novo shall be afforded the appellant
within thirty days after receipt of such transcript.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.12 SUBPOENA OF WITNESSES.
   The Board shall have, and is hereby granted, the power to subpoena within
Cuyahoga County and require the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the
production of books, papers, public records and other documentary evidence
pertinent to its hearing on appeal or applications, as is authorized by this
Code. It may examine or permit examination, including cross-examination, of any
such witness in relation to the appeal, application or any matter in which it
has authority to hear and determine.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.13 PRECIPE; WITNESS FEES.
   A precipe for a subpoena may be filed by any party under the rules of the
Board of Zoning Appeals. Witnesses may be subpoenaed and their attendance
compelled within Cuyahoga County, Ohio. Fees shall be allowed to witnesses on
their certificate and shall be paid by the Treasurer of the Village on warrants
issued by the Clerk for attendance and traveling, as is provided in Ohio R.C.
2335.06 for witnesses in courts of record. Such fees and travel allowance shall
be taxed as costs of the appeal, or proceeding. The Board may require a deposit
for the subpoena of any witness at the time of filing of the precipe but no
deposit shall be required in the case of a witness subpoenaed on behalf of an
administrative officer or the Village. The Police Department shall be
responsible for the serving of subpoenaes and enforcement of the Board's
orders.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.14 DISOBEDIENCE OF SUBPOENA.
   In case any person willfully fails to obey a subpoena of the Board of Zoning
Appeals or secretes himself to avoid being served a subpoena, or refuses to be
sworn or to affirm, or refuses to answer a question required to be answered, he
shall be charged as provided in Ohio R.C. Ch. 2705 and shall be subject to the
penalties thereunder.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.15 HEARING PROCEDURE.
   The hearing of any appeal or application by the Board of Zoning Appeals
shall proceed as in the trial of a civil action. Any contiguous or neighboring
property owner especially affected by the appeal or application, may become a
party thereto. The appellant or any party shall be permitted to appear and be
heard in person or by his attorney and to present his position, arguments and
contentions, to offer and examine witnesses, and present evidence, to cross-
examine witnesses, to offer evidence, to refute evidence and testimony offered
in opposition to his position, arguments and contentions and to proffer any
such evidence into the record. The testimony adduced shall be given under oath.
Every person who submits to testimony shall be sworn. Any party may call any
other party as if on cross-examination.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.16 APPEAL FROM BOARD.
   Upon the filing of a notice of appeal as provided in Ohio R.C. Chapter 2506
and an appropriate precipe, the secretary of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
prepare a transcript as required by law and file the same in the court to which
the appeal is taken, provided such notice of appeal is filed within the period
allowed by law. Such transcript shall contain the original papers, testimony,
if available, and evidence offered, heard and taken in consideration of the
order appealed from. The secretary shall require a deposit as provided by
ordinance, together with the actual cost of reducing the testimony to writing,
and all such costs shall be taxed as a part of the cost of the appeal.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1121.17 FINAL ORDER.
   In rendering any final order, adjudication or decision, the Board of Zoning
Appeals shall make and file conclusions of fact supporting such order,
adjudication or decision.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1123
Enforcement and Penalty
 
1123.01    Enforcing authority.
1123.02    Permits issued to be in conformance to code.
1123.03    Greater restriction to control.
1123.04    Village uses not restricted.
1123.05    Revocation of permits.
1123.06    Injunction.
1123.07    Transfer of unplatted land.
1123.08    Violation of Commission regulation.
1123.09    Transfer or change of use of common land prohibited.
1123.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Building Commissioner to administer and enforce - see ADM.
145.03
Building Commissioner to issue occupancy permits - see ADM.
145.05, P. & Z.
1125.01
Violation of zoning ordinances - see Ohio R.C. 713.13
 
   1123.01 ENFORCING AUTHORITY.
   The administration and enforcement of this Code shall be vested in the
Commissioner of Buildings and his assistants.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.02 PERMITS ISSUED TO BE IN CONFORMANCE TO CODE.
   All departments, officers and employees of the Village, vested with any duty
or authority over the issuance of permits or licenses, shall conform to the
provisions of this Code and shall not issue and permit or license for any use,
building or purpose if the same would conflict with any such provision. A
permit or license issued in conflict with any such provision shall be void and
shall have no legal effect.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.03 GREATER RESTRICTION TO CONTROL.
   In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Code, they shall be held
to the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health,
safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. They do not prevent other
more restrictive requirements. Where this Code imposes greater restrictions on
the use of buildings or premises, or requires larger open spaces, than are
imposed or required by other codes, laws, ordinances, rules or regulations, the
provisions of this Code shall govern.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.04 VILLAGE USES NOT RESTRICTED.
   No provision of this Code shall in any way restrict the use of lands or
buildings owned or occupied by the Village for municipal purposes. It is the
intention of Council to retain and reserve to the Village its sovereign rights
to the free and unrestricted use of lands and buildings which it owns for
municipal purposes, notwithstanding any purpose or provision of this Code.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.05 REVOCATION OF PERMITS.
   Any permit issued under this Code shall be revocable should any of the
conditions, under which it is issued, be not complied with.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.06 INJUNCTION.
   No person shall erect, construct, alter or repair or maintain any building
or structure, or use any land in violation of this Code or the regulations
enacted pursuant thereto. In the event of any such violation, or imminent
threat thereof, upon the request of the Mayor or Council, the Solicitor, on
behalf of the Village, shall institute a suit for injunction to prevent or
terminate such violation.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.07 TRANSFER OF UNPLATTED LAND.
   Whoever, being the owner or agent of the owner of any unplatted lot or
parcel of land within the Village, willfully divides and transfers a portion of
any such lot, parcel or tract of land by metes and bounds description without
the prior approval of the Planning Commission as provided in Chapter
1133, shall forfeit and pay the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each lot, parcel or tract of land
so transferred, as determined by Council. Such sum shall be recovered, with
costs, in an action brought by the Solicitor in the name of the Village and for
the use of the Street Repair Fund.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.08 VIOLATION OF COMMISSION REGULATION.
   Whoever willfully violates any rule or regulation adopted by Council or the
Planning Commission, or fails to comply with any order issued pursuant to Ohio
R.C. Chapter 711 or 713 or this Code, shall forfeit and pay not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) to be
recovered with costs in a civil action brought by the Solicitor in the name of
the Village for the use thereof. Each day such violation continues shall
constitute a separate forfeiture.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1123.09 TRANSFER OR CHANGE OF USE OF COMMON LAND PROHIBITED.
   When common land, private ways, recreation areas, park or other open land
has been set aside for the exclusive use in common of owners or occupants of
dwellings in a planned development area, by plans or documents approved by the
Planning Commission and/or Council, the sale, division, transfer or change of
use of such land or any part thereof is prohibited unless such previously
approved plan is duly amended or the Planning Commission has given its prior
consent thereto, which consent shall be approved by action of Council before
becoming effective. Whoever willfully violates this section shall forfeit and
pay to the Village not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000) as determined by
Council. Such sum shall be recovered, with costs, in an action brought by the
Solicitor in the name of the Village and for the use thereof.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
 
   1123.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who:
(a)    Uses or occupies any land, or places, builds, erects, alters, remodels,
restores, or rebuilds thereon any building or structure, or permits any
building or structure to remain on such land, or uses, occupies or operates
such building or structure in any way or for any use or purpose which is not
permitted by the provisions of this Code, or
(b)    Aids, assists or participates with any person in placing, building,
erecting, altering, remodeling, restoring or rebuilding any building or
structure which is not permitted by the provisions of this Code, or
(c)    Violates or fails to perform any condition, stipulation or safeguard set
forth in any permit issued pursuant to this Code, or continues to use or occupy
the premises or building as previously authorized by such permit beyond the
duration limit therein stated, or
(d)    Refuses to permit the Commissioner of Buildings or his assistant to
enter any premises in the Village to investigate a reported violation of the
provisions of this Code, or
(e)    Knowingly makes any materially false statement of fact in an application
to the Commissioner of Buildings or his assistants for a permit or in any plans
or specifications submitted in relation to any application under this Code, or
(f)    Being an owner or lessee of any premises, knowingly permits a violation
of this Code to occur or exist on such premises,
shall, by each such action or omission, be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). Each day during which such act, violation or omission is
done, committed, omitted or continued, shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1125
Occupancy Permits
 
1125.01    Requirement.
1125.02    Timing of application.
1125.03    Plat required.
1125.04    Application information.
1125.05    Issuance.
1125.06    Fees.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Occupancy permit defined - see P. & Z.
1111.12
Conference center permit - see P. & Z.
1127.01
Building permits - see BLDG. Ch.
1311
Moving a building; permit - see BLDG.
1323.01,
1323.03,
1323.07
Swimming pool permit - see BLDG.
1329.01
 
   1125.01 REQUIREMENT.
   An occupancy permit shall be required to be issued by the Commissioner of
Buildings for any new use or for change of use of land or structure or for a
nonconforming use or structure.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1125.02 TIMING OF APPLICATION.
   An occupancy permit shall be applied for:
   (a)    Simultaneously with the application for a building permit, or
   (b)    At the time of change in use of land or structure, or
   (c)    In the case of a nonconforming use or structure within one year after
the effective date of this Code or any subsequent amendment which creates
nonconformity.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1125.03 PLAT REQUIRED.
   All applications for occupancy permits shall be accompanied by a site plan
or plat, in triplicate, which shows:
(a)    The street providing access to the land;
(b)    Lot numbers, if any, of the concerned and abutting properties;
(c)    Dimensions and location of structures;
(d)    Location and size of proposed structure; and
(e)    Any other information deemed by the Commissioner of Buildings necessary
for the enforcement of this Code.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1125.04 APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Application forms shall be provided by the Commissioner of Buildings. Each
application shall state that no part of the land involved has been previously
used to provide an open space for another structure. It shall be attested to as
to correctness of statements and data by the property owner.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1125.05 ISSUANCE.
   No building permit shall be issued unless the structure and use proposed in
the application for occupancy permit conform to the provisions of this Code. An
occupancy permit shall be issued upon examination of the completed structure or
structural alterations and certification by the Commissioner of Buildings
within ten days after completion that the structure or alteration has been
completed in conformity with this Code. If only a change in use of land or
structure is involved, an occupancy permit may be issued immediately.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1125.06 FEES.
   Application and other fees shall be charged as provided by ordinance. A copy
of the occupancy permit and plat shall be furnished on request to any
interested person.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1127
Special Permit for Conference Center
 
1127.01    Intent.
1127.02    Definition and use.
1127.03    Issuance procedures, application information and public hearings.
1127.04    Area and yard requirements.
1127.05    Off-street parking.
1127.06    Screening of off-street parking space.
1127.07    Hours and attendance.
1127.08    Term of permit.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Occupancy permit - see P. & Z.
1125.01
Permit to move a building - see BLDG.
1323.01,
1323.03,
1323.07
Swimming pool permit - see BLDG.
1329.01
 
   1127.01 INTENT.
   A primary objective of the Village is to encourage the preservation of the
traditional architectural character and image of the community. The
preservation and continued maintenance of the large residential estates, which
exist in many areas of the Village, shall contribute to the achievement of this
objective. Therefore, as a means to foster preservation and maintenance of the
buildings and grounds of such properties, the Village may consider an
application for a special permit for a conference center use on parcels within
the R-1 Standard Single-Family District, where such use shall result in the
preservation, restoration and maintenance of the original principal residential
structures and the preservation, restoration and maintenance of the general
character of the landscaped grounds associated with the original residence. No
special permit for conference center use shall be issued unless the Planning
Commission, with the advice of the Design Review Board, finds that the proposed
conference center use shall further the objectives of the Village and the
purposes and intent of this Code and this section, and that the proposed
conference center use shall have no substantial adverse affect upon adjoining
properties and the surrounding areas of the Village, and that the development
and operation of the proposed conference center use shall be in accordance with
the standards, requirements and procedures set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
 
   1127.02 DEFINITION AND USE.
   For the purposes of this chapter "conference center use" means the use of an
existing principal residential structure on a lot, developed and used in the
manner prescribed by this chapter, by one or more nonprofit colleges or
universities certified pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1713.02 or by a charitable
corporation established pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1702 for educational
conferences, seminars and meetings related to the educational and civic
improvement programs of such institutions and for the purpose of promoting the
cultural arts, horticulture, education and civic affairs of the community and
the institution.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
 
   1127.03 ISSUANCE PROCEDURES, APPLICATION INFORMATION AND PUBLIC HEARINGS.
   In any R-1 Standard Residential District, the Commissioner of Buildings may
issue a special permit for the location and use of a conference center as
described and according to the procedures prescribed in this chapter after
approval thereof by the Planning Commission. Approval of the issuance of a
special permit for a conference center may be given by the Commission upon
application made therefor by the owner of the property to be so used. Before
the issuance of such special permit, the Commission shall give public notice
and hold a public hearing. The application shall include or be accompanied by:
(a)    A description of the lot and the buildings and the improvements located
or to be located thereon with sufficient specificity to show compliance with
this chapter;
(b)    Name and purposes of the organization which it is proposed shall use the
conference center;
(c)    The building and land use which is proposed;
(d)    The nature and frequency of the proposed use;
(e)    Evidence of financial responsibility and ability to maintain the
property and use, satisfactory to the Planning Commission;
(f)    Such additional evidence as the Commission may reasonably require to
demonstrate that the conditions and standards prescribed by this chapter for
the approval of such a special permit shall be complied with and maintained;
and
(g)    Evidence satisfactory to the Commission that the use of the conference
center shall not result in a loss of tax income to the Village.
   The Commission may impose such additional conditions for the issuance of a
special permit as it may deem necessary for the protection of the public peace,
health, safety and welfare, and for the preservation and protection of property
values and enjoyment of neighboring property.
(Ord. 2242. Passed 7-13-81.)
 
   1127.04 AREA AND YARD REQUIREMENTS.
   A conference center must be located on a lot at least six acres in area held
in one ownership. The minimum yard sizes prescribed in Section
1155.04 shall not apply, but instead the lot used as a conference center shall
have a minimum front yard of 350 feet, two side yards of at least 100 feet
each, and a minimum rear yard of 100 feet, except that, where the rear of the
lot adjoins Lake Erie or any public open space, no rear yard shall be required,
and except that the Planning Commission at the time of approval of use of the
property as a conference center, may approve the continued location of existing
accessory buildings within such minimum yard space. Landscaping shall be
provided to insure privacy to adjoining properties, and buildings and grounds
shall be maintained in attractive, safe and orderly condition in keeping with
community standards.
(Ord. 1805. Passed 6-18-69.)
 
   1127.05 OFF-STREET PARKING.
   An off-street parking area or areas shall be provided equal to one-half the
gross floor area of the main building devoted to such use, shall contain not
less than forty parking spaces, and may be located in part or entirely off the
premises if:
(a)    The nearest parking spaces are within 400 feet of the nearest boundary
of the lot upon which such use granted by special permit is located, measured
by a straight line between the points, and
(b)    The premises used for off-street parking are either owned or controlled
by the same ownership as the premises for which such special use permit may be
granted.
   Exterior lighting provided for the parking area or areas shall be
constructed and arranged to prevent the direct emission of light upon adjoining
lots or public streets.
(Ord. 1805. Passed 6-18-69.)
 
   1127.06 SCREENING OF OFF-STREET PARKING SPACE.
   Where five or more off-street parking spaces are provided, and are located
on a lot that adjoins or is across the street from a lot on which there is a
building containing dwelling units, such parking spaces shall be screened
therefrom by an opaque wall, a uniformly painted fence of fire resistant
material, or a strip of land at least four feet wide planted with shrubs that
form a dense screen. Such wall, fence or shrubs shall be at least three feet in
height but such wall or fence shall be not more than six feet in height. Such
wall, fence or shrubs located within fifteen feet of the intersection of two or
more streets, or the intersection of an access driveway and a street, shall
have a maximum height of three feet and a minimum height of two feet. The
required screening shall be maintained in good condition at all times. No signs
shall be attached to or hung from the required screening.
(Ord. 1805. Passed 6-18-69.)
 
   1127.07 HOURS AND ATTENDANCE.
   A conference center may operate on any day, but only between 8:00 a.m. and
11:00 p.m. No conference center event shall have an attendance of more than 300
persons at any one time, except with prior approval of the Commissioner of
Buildings. Such prior approval shall be granted only if the Commissioner finds
that the attendance of more than 300 persons can safely be accommodated and
will not adversely affect the enjoyment of neighboring property. In making such
decision, the Commissioner shall take into consideration the degree to which
the attendance exceeds 300, the nature of the conference center event and the
hours during which such event shall take place.
(Ord. 1805. Passed 6-18-69.)
 
   1127.08 TERM OF PERMIT.
   Such special use permit shall be issued or renewed by the Commissioner of
Buildings, but not for a period of more than three years, as shall be approved
by the Planning Commission. Any failure or refusal of the permit holder to
comply with the ordinances of the Village or the standards and conditions of
the permit shall constitute revocation thereof. Any change in ownership or any
change in the user of the premises or of any part thereof shall render the
permit void unless within thirty days after such change application is made to
the Commissioner for transfer of such permit and such transfer shall be
approved by the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 1805. Passed 6-18-69.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1129
Nonconformance
 
1129.01   Existing lawful uses.
1129.02   Discontinuance of use.
1129.03   Abandonment of use.
1129.04   Restoration of damaged structure.
1129.05   Extension of nonconforming building.
1129.06   Use addition prohibited.
1129.07   Nonconforming change prohibited.
1129.08   Moving nonconforming structure.
1129.09   Future amendments.
1129.10   Nonconforming lots.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Nonconforming uses, retroactive measures - see Ohio R.C. 713.15
Nonconforming structure, lot and use defined - see P. & Z.
1111.11
 
   1129.01 EXISTING LAWFUL USES.
   The lawful use of any dwelling, building or structure and of any land or
premises as existing and lawful at the time of enacting this Code may be
continued although such use does not conform to the provisions of this Code.
The completion, restoration, reconstruction, extension or substitution of
nonconforming uses shall be subject to the provisions and conditions set forth
in this chapter.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.02 DISCONTINUANCE OF USE.
   Any nonconforming use of land or building which has ceased by voluntary
discontinuance or abandonment for a period of at least one year shall be
presumed to have been abandoned, subject to permission for re-instatement by
the Board of Zoning Appeals, after hearing.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.03 ABANDONMENT OF USE.
   Any nonconforming use of land or building, which is voluntarily discontinued
for two years or more, shall be conclusively presumed to have been abandoned
and any future use of the land or building shall be in conformity to the
provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.04 RESTORATION OF DAMAGED STRUCTURE.
   Any nonconforming building which has been destroyed or damaged by fire,
other casualty, act of God or by a public enemy to the extent of fifty percent
or more of its cost of restoration to the condition in which it was before the
occurrence, shall thereafter conform to the provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.05 EXTENSION OF NONCONFORMING BUILDING.
   (a)   No nonconforming building shall be enlarged or structurally altered,
unless:
(1)   The building with any proposed extension is made to conform to the
regulations of the district in which it is located; or
(2)   The extension will not increase any existing nonconformity; or
(3)   The building extension will reduce a nonconforming condition.
 
   (b)   A nonconforming use may not be extended within the building.
(Ord. 3070. Passed 7-18-01.)
 
   1129.06 USE ADDITION PROHIBITED.
   A nonconforming use may not be enlarged, added to in any manner, or be
replaced by another nonconforming use.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.07 NONCONFORMING CHANGE PROHIBITED.
   The use of a nonconforming building may be changed only to a use conforming
to the district in which the building is located.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.08 MOVING NONCONFORMING STRUCTURE.
   A nonconforming structure may be moved to a different location on the same
lot or other parcel of land within the district, with approval of the Board of
Zoning Appeals, after hearing, and provided proper and adequate alterations are
secured to make the structure conform to the regulations of the district where
it is located.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.09 FUTURE AMENDMENTS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall also apply to nonconforming uses in
districts hereinafter changed by amendment to this Code.
(Ord. 1600. Passed 7-26-62.)
 
   1129.10 NONCONFORMING LOTS.
   A lot of record that does not comply on the effective date of this Planning
and Zoning Code, or any amendment thereto, with the lot area or lot width
regulations of the district in which the lot is located may be used as follows:
(a)   Existing Dwelling on a Residential Lot. If the lot is occupied by a
dwelling, such dwelling shall be maintained and may be repaired, modernized or
altered, provided that the building shall not be enlarged in floor area unless
the enlarged section(s) complies with the land coverage, floor area, height,
building setback requirements and all regulations of this Planning and Zoning
Code, except the lot area and lot width regulations of the district in which
the lot is located.
(b)   Vacant Single Nonconforming Lot of Record. A vacant nonconforming lot
that is in separate ownership and not of continuous frontage with other lots in
the same ownership shall be permitted to be developed as a site for a single-
family dwelling provided that the dwelling and its accessory uses comply with
the land coverage, floor area, height, building setback requirements and all
regulations of this Planning and Zoning Code, except the lot area and lot width
regulations of the district in which the lot is located.
(c)   Lots in Combination. If a vacant nonconforming lot adjoins one or more
lots in common ownership on the effective date of this Code or applicable
amendment thereto, such lot shall be replatted to create conforming lots as a
prerequisite for development.
(d)   Variance from Compliance with Code. In reviewing a variance request for a
proposed single-family dwelling or changes to an existing single-family
dwelling on a nonconforming lot that do not comply with all regulations of this
Planning and Zoning Code, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall consider whether
the bulk and height of the proposed structure or alteration is substantially in
excess of the current zoning requirements for the dwelling, and if such change
will increase the nonconforming condition(s) of the lot.
(Ord. 3070. Passed 7-18-01.)
 
 
 
TITLE FIVE - Subdivision Control
Chap.
1133.    Procedure for Plat Approval.
Chap.
1135.    Planning Criteria.
Chap.
